Chapter 34

◎Combined Two Chapters◎

Nanny Fan had always assumed that Huiyin was someone who loved to compete for power. However, unexpectedly, after she arrived in Jianye, she had been taking care of her child and rarely went out. The servants all said that the young princess consort had a calm demeanor and conducted herself with propriety. The courtyard was in perfect order. Even now, when she was going to the Huo family, she first sent someone to inquire about the travel arrangements and the gift list sent previously, and so on.

Because Grand Dowager Wu had inexplicably become angry again, she had been saying for the past few days that she would not go out. When Wei Imperial Consort sent someone to invite her over for a visit, she declined, citing poor health.

Nanny Fan brought in a few snacks and saw that Grand Dowager Wu looked gloomy. She forced a smile and said, "The kitchen has made some new snacks, and I was asked to bring them for you to try."

Grand Dowager Wu said, "I'm old and don't like eating these anymore. Besides, these tea-serving tasks should be done by the young girls. You don't need to do it yourself."

But Nanny Fan knew that if she became complacent, she would lose her standing with Grand Dowager Wu. So she smiled and said, "Serving you is my joy and duty. I wouldn't trust others to do it."

This response pleased Grand Dowager Wu, who, despite saying she didn't want snacks, took half and put it in her mouth, complaining, "There's too much sugar frosting, and it's not soft enough. I said last time not to use the osmanthus honey and cassia honey, but they went ahead and used cassia honey again."

Even though she nearly finished the plate, she still found fault and never acknowledged the good.

Nanny Fan said, "I will reprimand them. This Mrs. Wang, who makes the snacks, is too incompetent."

After Grand Dowager Wu finished her snacks and went back to her morning prayers, Nanny Fan left and saw Mrs. Wang looking very happy. She stopped her and asked, "Why are you so cheerful? Did something good happen?"

"The young princess consort praised my snacks and rewarded me with a thousand coins. It's not about the money, but the princess consort is kind, and we suffer less reprimanding because of her." What Mrs. Wang meant was that Huiyin heard she had a daughter who couldn't do heavy work due to poor health and couldn't get a position in the mansion. The young princess consort said she needed a third-class maid, which made Mrs. Wang extremely happy.

But she couldn't tell Nanny Fan this, as secrets are best kept silent.

Nanny Fan saw through the situation and, comparing the actions of Princess Zheng and Grand Dowager Wu, had a clear understanding. Although Grand Dowager Wu was the same as before, there had been no comparisons previously. The mansion only had one mistress, Grand Dowager Wu. But now, with the young princess consort here, it's no surprise she can easily win people over.

Grand Dowager Wu was more astute in her younger days, but now she was old and confused. Previously, there was Xun Rou, who was only in charge of accounts and demanded frightening amounts of silver.

Since they were visiting the Huo family, Huiyin naturally needed to prepare birthday gifts. The chief steward in Jianye was one of Grand Dowager Wu's long-time servants, though not technically a dowry attendant. It was clear without even looking that since Grand Dowager Wu's people had made a fortune in Xuzhou, they wouldn't be honest and upright in Jianye, and the corruption here might be even worse.

But now wasn't the time to expose them. Everything required the right timing, location, and harmony.

"Is this the gift list from before? Why is it so thin?" Huiyin frowned.

Steward Qian smiled and said, "Originally, we sent gifts from Jianye to various places, but later the Little Prince said he would send them directly from Xuzhou, so we didn't..."

"I see, but now that I'm here, we'll send them from this side. For the Huo family's old lady's birthday, having only longevity noodles, longevity peaches, and a cane is not enough. Is there any 'Three Friends of Cold' silk in the storeroom? That is royal silk, and it would be very prestigious to use it as a gift." Huiyin said.

Steward Qian was in a difficult position and said, "Young Princess Consort, it's not that I'm making excuses, but Grand Dowager Wu seemed to have given the royal silk to someone."

This was insincere, as there was quite a lot of royal silk, and it wouldn't be given away casually.

Huiyin had no choice but to say, "Then take it from my share. We can't appear too shabby. The Huo family is not an ordinary family. If the gifts are too meager, it will be a loss of face for Huaiyin Mansion."

She asked Nanny Nan to open the western storeroom, where her dowry and the mansion's treasures were kept. They took not only the 'Three Friends of Cold' royal silk but also prepared a pair of green glass vases with purple floral patterns and a sandalwood base with a jasper Buddha's hand. Only then was Huiyin satisfied.

In any case, in Jiang Bipbo's matter, Huo Qi refrained from causing trouble out of respect for her.

Sending heavier gifts was also about building goodwill. The Huo family wasn't just Huo Qi alone. Moreover, from a business perspective, the items Jiang Bipbo had sent over were already more valuable than these.

Seeing these birthday gifts, Steward Qian couldn't help but nod in approval. This truly showed the grandeur of a prince's mansion. If you have the means to impress, people will be more likely to support you, knowing you have the resources.

After the birthday gifts were prepared, Huiyin finally breathed a sigh of relief.

Unfortunately, Yin Liyi came to visit. She really had an urgent matter and, upon seeing Huiyin, looked as if she had found a savior. "Young Princess Consort, I really need to ask a favor of you. You must agree to help me."

"What is it? Why are you asking me for help?" Huiyin was puzzled.

Yin Liyi continued, "I intend to go to Qingzhou to take care of my husband, but the Prince of Wei said that while it's fine for me to go, the situation ahead is chaotic. If the travel permit is issued for Qingzhou and we are caught halfway, it could cause trouble. Therefore, we plan to take a detour and select Jizhou as our destination instead. Since you are the daughter of the Grand Commander of Jizhou, I have come to seek your help."

It turned out that this was her plan. Yin Liyi was different from Jiang Bibo. Helping Jiang Bibo meant saving a life, but helping Yin Liyi now might lead to harm, and there could even be repercussions for herself.

"The journey to Qingzhou is long, and I would have difficulty going there myself, so how could I possibly help you? When I first married into the family, our wedding procession was almost ambushed," Huiyin declined politely.

Yin Liyi was not willing to give up. "Little Princess, what I need is a personal letter from you."

"Lady Yin, how could my personal letter compare to one from the Prince of Wei? Even this year, I couldn't send gifts back home because of the war," Huiyin shook her head.

Yin Liyi found Huiyin difficult to persuade, while Huiyin thought that Yin Liyi was trying to push the risk onto her. If Yin Liyi used her name to go to Qingzhou and something happened, wouldn't that cause trouble for her?

Seeing that Huiyin still disagreed, Yin Liyi had no choice but to go and pay her respects to the Grand Dowager Wu. Her request was simple: if the Little Princess couldn't help her, she would ask Li Cheng's men to escort her. The Prince of Wei said he could send someone to escort her, but he couldn't spare many people, and since the front was a military camp, he, as a prince, couldn't break military orders.

Thus, after paying her respects to the Grand Dowager Wu, Yin Liyi left resolutely.

Nanny Nan had never really liked Yin Liyi, and as soon as she left, she said, "I've always thought she was a troublemaker. She couldn't get the prince's support, so now she's going to ask the Little Prince?"

Huiyin smiled. "Then let her ask."

"But if something goes wrong on the journey, the Little Prince could be blamed," Nanny Nan explained.

Huiyin said coldly, "That would be his problem. If he can't stay firm in the face of such a small issue, he's bound to stumble at every step in the future. Yin Liyi clearly acts impulsively, without much thought for the consequences. If she sent a skilled physician to the frontlines instead of going herself, it would be much better. Is she a doctor?"

Regardless of Yin Liyi's situation, after Huiyin dressed herself properly, she went to the Huo family to offer birthday congratulations.

When the elderly Madame Huo heard the birthday gifts being announced, and it came to the Huaiyin Mansion's gift, she couldn't help but say, "Having a mistress in the household makes a difference."

Madame Huo, the mother of the Princess of Wei, smiled. "Indeed, the previous gifts were also generous, but not as substantial as they are now."

"We shouldn't criticize the gifts from the princes," Madame Huo certainly wouldn't give anyone a reason to gossip.

Madame Huo nodded in agreement, but the joy on their faces was unmistakable. After all, the birthday celebration of the elderly Madame Huo was a great honor, and the Princess of Wei was returning to her natal family to celebrate. This naturally made the Huo family overjoyed.

As Huiyin approached the Huo family residence, she gently lifted the carriage curtain and saw the colorful pavilions and lanterns at the entrance, which looked extremely grand. The housekeeper, Lady Liu, who accompanied her, said, "Little Princess, the elderly Madame Huo is usually compassionate and sympathetic. She doesn't usually make such a high-profile display, but because it's her birthday, the celebration is particularly lively. It's said that the Princess of Wei is preparing to visit and offer birthday congratulations."

Huiyin nodded slightly, and when the carriage stopped, the women of the Huo family were already waiting to perform the ceremonial greetings.

"Please rise, there's no need for such grand rituals. Dear elder, last time at Zhaoming Palace, we didn't have much chance to talk. Today, let's spend more time together," Huiyin personally helped the elderly Madame Huo to her feet.

The elderly Madame Huo had found Huiyin to be composed and dignified the last time they met, and today, her words were thoughtful and appropriate. Being experienced, she didn't dare to show any other thoughts and only said, "As long as the Little Princess doesn't find this old woman too talkative."

Huiyin smiled slightly.

The rest of the Huo family members found her young but extremely authoritative due to her reserved speech, which made them more respectful and somewhat fearful.

This was exactly what Huiyin wanted. When she was younger, her personality was lively, and she spoke without reserve. Later, she realized that being too sincere with people allowed them to see through her quickly, and they lost interest in her.

Moreover, when people are too familiar with each other, it becomes difficult to speak freely. With some distance, there are fewer reservations.

As soon as she settled into her seat, Madame Huo turned to Huiyin and said, "I heard that Lady Yin came to seek your help? That she needed your assistance to go to Qingzhou?"

"Yes, she came to my mansion, but how could I have been of any help?" Huiyin smiled and shook her head.

Madame Huo and the elderly Madame Huo exchanged a glance, both somewhat surprised. After all, the couple Xie Jiuyi and Princess Zheng were quite close to Li Cheng, and both Xie Jiuyi and Li Cheng were key supporters of the Prince of Wei. It seemed that Princess Zheng and Lady Yin had some discord.

But the two of them weren't foolish enough to ask directly.

The elderly Madame Huo then asked the younger sisters of the Princess of Wei to come out and meet the guest. They were girls in their teenage years, and Huiyin took off a white jade bracelet from her own wrist and gave it to the two girls, praising them. "It's no surprise that you are the sisters of the Princess of Wei. Your bearing and demeanor are truly exceptional."

The two ladies of the Huo family stood with graceful smiles and elegant demeanor.

"I wonder if the two ladies have been betrothed?" Huiyin asked.

Elderly Madame Huo smiled. "Not yet, they are still quite young."

Huiyin said, "They are both fine young women, and with your esteemed status, they will surely find suitable matches."

Everyone exchanged pleasantries, and the return of the Princess of Wei was mentioned. Everyone stood up again to welcome her. Once seated, the Princess of Wei and Huiyin took their places at the eastern and western tables, followed by the marquises, and then Elderly Madame Huo and the others.

The Huo family's banquet was exceptionally well-prepared, with dishes that were refreshing and not at all greasy, compared to usual banquets.

Huiyin had come today to assess the Huo family's stance on her decision to protect Jiang Bipbo. The women in the inner chambers typically followed the men's lead. Now that the Princess of Wei had returned, she would wait and see.

After the banquet, Second Madam Huo offered opera scripts for the Princess of Wei and Huiyin to choose from. As they watched the opera, the Princess of Wei said to Huiyin, "Is everything settled for you? When you have time, come to our mansion to pay respects to our Empress Dowager. She often thinks of Elderly Madame Wu and your family."

Huiyin offered some polite remarks.

Then the Princess of Wei asked, "Have you ever visited Jianye, young princess?"

"I haven't actually. When I came here, my child fell ill, and I had to take care of them at home. I didn't have the leisure to tour around. I wonder, where do you usually spend your leisure time, Lady Wang?" Huiyin gently blew on her tea foam.

The Princess of Wei smiled. "With our status, we don't often go out. Before, we used to play in Cheng Garden, which is vast with a horse racing track and a garden. That garden took ten years to build and was exquisitely beautiful. Later, I heard it was bought by a salt merchant with the surname Jiang, and we stopped going."

A salt merchant with the surname Jiang? Huiyin knew exactly what this meant. She put down her teacup and said, "When I was in Xuzhou, I met a young lady with the surname Jiang. We got along very well and became sworn sisters. I wonder if we are talking about the same family?"

"I wouldn't know about that," the Princess of Wei said, keeping her distance. She didn't want to offend Li Cheng and Princess Zheng. Li Cheng, known for his bravery and reliability, and Princess Zheng, the daughter of the Marquis of Zhaojie and the Grand Commander, both held very high status.

Huiyin instantly understood the Princess of Wei's implication: our Huo family is letting this go out of respect for you, but don't push it too far in the future.

Outsiders, unaware of the subtle dynamics, would think the two were getting along very well.

The Princess of Wei had matters to discuss with her family as well, so after the opera, Huiyin took her leave, and they saw off their guests before closing the door to talk privately.

"The prince intends to make the son of Consort Xu the official heir, but Consort Yin's son is the eldest. If it were up to me, I would favor Consort Yin's son, but the prince may not agree," the Princess of Wei said.

Elderly Madame Huo remained silent at first, while Madame Huo, somewhat anxious, said, "Then, my lady, you must not let that Xu woman take advantage of the situation. Consort Yin is close to our family and has always followed your lead, despite once being favored."

Elderly Madame Huo looked at the Princess of Wei. "The young princes are still very young. Why the rush? If you were to have a child, what would their status matter?"

"Your comforting words ease my heart, grandmother. A few days ago, when the Princess of Huaiyin first married into the family and gave birth to a son with great fanfare, it kept me awake at night. The prince married me when he was fifteen, just three years older than the Prince of Huaiyin. In our eleven years of marriage, we have only two sons and one daughter. It is my fault." The Princess of Wei wiped her tears with a handkerchief.

The Huo family quickly reassured the Princess of Wei, who then added, "In the future, please advise your second brother to be more restrained and serve the prince faithfully."

This was a subtle reminder to the Huo family. In front of outsiders, she had to maintain the dignity of her natal family, but she also needed to caution them.

It was also known that after learning the Huo family's stance, Huiyin felt more at ease.

**

Meanwhile, Yin Liyi secretly took a small boat to Xuzhou and, three days later, arrived at Huaiyin Mansion. Li Cheng, of course, had not yet gone to Qingzhou. As Huiyin had said, most of his soldiers were in Xuzhou. If they were lost, he would have no troops left.

At that moment, he was informed that Yin Liyi had arrived. Li Cheng frowned, "What does she want?"

Wasn't she supposed to be in Xuzhou with Huiyin?

"Lady Xie said she has a letter from the Prince of Wei."

"Then let her in."

Yin Liyi, seeing that Huiyin refused to help her, decided to come directly to Xuzhou. It was her sister, Yin Lifang, who came up with the idea to obtain a letter from the Prince of Wei, knowing that Li Cheng could not disobey the prince's orders.

"Here, I’ll make the necessary arrangements for you," Li Cheng said as Yin Liyi handed him the letter without a word.

Raising an eyebrow, Li Cheng remarked, "I didn’t expect the Prince of Wei to write a letter himself. For you to get the Prince of Wei to write for you, you’ve certainly come a long way."

"Cheng Brother, are you mocking me?" Yin Liyi felt attacked once again.

Li Cheng shook his head. "Originally, I definitely wouldn’t want you to go to Qingzhou. Given the ongoing conflict, no one can predict what will happen. But since you insist and have the backing of the Prince of Wei, I’ll arrange for someone to assist you."

Yin Liyi was somewhat surprised by how readily Li Cheng agreed. She had considered mentioning that Huiyin refused to help but, for some reason, she kept quiet. She had a vague feeling that if she revealed Princess Zheng’s refusal, Li Cheng might hesitate as well. After a moment’s thought, she hesitated but then said, "Actually, I didn’t expect the Prince of Wei to help me either. It was my sister who advised me."

"Your elder sister," Li Cheng said, lowering his gaze.

Yin Liyi smiled. "Yes, my sister is smarter than me. I originally wanted to come directly, but my sister told me you’re someone who strictly follows official procedures. Without the Prince of Wei’s order, you definitely wouldn’t arrange it for me. My mind isn’t as quick as my sister’s. When I was a female official, she was already smarter and more meticulous than me."

"Alright, go back to your residence. I’ll arrange everything today, and you can set off again tomorrow," Li Cheng, known for his efficiency in handling matters, said.

It was already dusk when Yin Liyi arrived, and it would be night by the time she returned to the mansion. She would leave for Qingzhou early the next morning, which seemed too soon.

However, Li Cheng didn’t ask further. He simply called Yuwendang over to make the arrangements. Yuwendang remarked, "I heard that General Xie is about to return. Why is Lady Xie going?"

"The Prince of Wei has agreed, so what can we say? Just arrange it," Li Cheng waved his hand.

Yuwendang left to follow his orders.

Afterward, Li Cheng went to the study, where his advisor Jian Tan was waiting. Li Cheng asked, "The Crown Prince has won a great victory. Mr. Jian advised me to wait and not send troops, but what if the Prince of Wei orders me to dispatch troops?"

Jian Tan smiled. "Then you can make excuses, saying there’s insufficient food supply. There was a famine this year, after all. That’s a ready-made reason."

"You’re right, but the Lü and He families have always been at odds. Even if we attack from Xuzhou, we might not necessarily lose." Li Cheng believed that one should strike when the opportunity arises. Although Li Heng had won a great victory, conflicts between the Lü and He families were inevitable in the long run.

Jian Tan said, "To my knowledge, the Crown Princess in the Eastern Palace is expecting a child. Think about it. If the Crown Princess gives birth to a son, won’t the Lü family support their own grandson? Would there still be a need for the Crown Prince? Without the Crown Prince to rely on, how could the He family maintain their influence? In this case, you should wait patiently."

Li Cheng nodded. "Alright, for now, I’ll focus on training the navy and, in the future, the infantry."

Jian Tan smiled. "A fine ambition, Little Prince."

...

Leaving the study, Li Cheng returned to his room. It was usually the liveliest place, with Huiyin and Jing’er around, but now he was alone.

For some reason, he felt restless and decided to take a walk outside.

He happened to run into Yun Hui, who had dressed up intentionally that day. Previously, she had dressed like a widow, but now she wore a delicate flower and had lightly colored her lips.

Noticing Li Cheng looking at her, Yun Hui blushed slightly, feeling both shy and embarrassed. "I just went out..."

Li Cheng was reminded of his time during a military campaign when he was chased and sought refuge in a nunnery. He was sixteen then and learned, for the first time, that nuns also engaged in less reputable business, entertaining male guests at night after their daytime religious duties. He didn’t want to think of Yun Hui in that light, but her new appearance and recent behavior suggested she had certain desires and didn’t want to leave the mansion. So, he tactfully said, "Yun Hui, you don’t have to observe widowhood. You’re still young."

Yun Hui was delighted, thinking that Li Cheng had finally noticed her. With Princess Zheng gone, she saw a great opportunity. Lately, she had started dressing up, not because she intended to mourn her late fiancé forever, but because she didn’t want to leave the mansion. Blushing, she said, "What you said is true, Little Prince. My mother also told me that I don’t have to cling to this. Her greatest hope is to see me marry into a good family."

"I feel the same. You’re still young; why waste your youth?" Li Cheng smiled.

Yun Hui pointed to her forehead. "Years ago, when you were mischievous and insisted on playing on the rockery, you were afraid to stand on top. I injured my forehead saving you, and the scar never healed. I did everything with all my heart," she said, hoping to convey her feelings and give Li Cheng a reason to take her in. Once it was settled, even if Princess Zheng returned, it would be too late to change things.

Li Cheng remembered that Yun Hui had been assigned as his head maid because of that incident. Granny Chao had been managing the household for many years, and according to Huiyin, Granny Chao’s private savings were even richer than some local landlords. Seeing Yun Hui bring up the past, Li Cheng didn’t hold it against her. "Yun Hui, you did indeed put in a lot of effort. So, if you get married, I’ll give you a generous dowry. Don’t worry. If the family is of high status, I can help arrange the match; if it’s lower, I can ensure a promising future for them."

As soon as he finished speaking, Yun Hui’s face turned pale, and she looked as if she might collapse at any moment.

title: Chapter 35
content:
Chapter 35

◎Combined Chapters◎

A new first-class maid named Shunfang had been promoted in Grand Dowager Wu's courtyard. Huiyin had heard plenty of rumors about Shunfang, who was bought from outside. Those who came in with her were only assigned to serve inside the chambers, but Shunfang had already become a first-class maid. Everyone was speculating about her connections.

In Huiyin's opinion, Shunfang's embroidery skills were not better than the others and could only be considered passable. Her seniority was only slightly higher than the granddaughter of Nanny Fan, yet it was she who got the promotion. This was a clear indication that the Huaiyin Mansion only employed those with strong connections, all vying to show whose backing was the strongest.

"Young Princess, the Dowager said that from now on, when you go to pay your respects, bring the heir along as well," Nanny Fan came to relay the message.

Huiyin smiled and said, "Alright, I understand."

Nanny Fan didn't expect Huiyin to agree so readily. She had thought Huiyin would refuse. Huiyin had one of her maids give Nanny Fan a reward and also kept her for a cup of tea, even giving her a new set of cosmetic boxes.

"I'll have someone deliver it to your quarters later. I heard that your eldest granddaughter is about to marry, so consider this my gift for her wedding," Huiyin said with a smile.

Nanny Fan thanked her repeatedly, "Thank you, Young Princess, for remembering."

"Yes, you may go now. I'm afraid if you stay too long, the Grand Dowager might blame you," Huiyin said considerately.

Nanny Fan had never revealed any secrets to Huiyin, but she always received rewards, and she knew that the Young Princess could handle many things on her own and didn't need her to do much. However, the more this happened, the more Nanny Fan felt obliged to repay her kindness. She needed to find an opportunity to return the favor.

It wasn't that Nanny Fan was particularly good or conscientious. Being the head maidservant by Grand Dowager Wu's side required more than just a conscience; she had even stepped on others and framed people before. But she was pragmatic.

It was clear who the future of the mansion belonged to. When the mistress took the initiative to extend an olive branch to her, if she didn't accept it, once Grand Dowager Wu passed away, she would become useless. If she could help the Young Princess even a little, she would still have a place in the mansion.

Once Nanny Fan left, Nanny Nan was anxious. "My lady, are you really going to bring the heir to pay respects? The weather is getting colder, and young children are most susceptible to wind."

Huiyin smiled, "Nanny Nan, what are you suggesting? Of course, I wouldn't do that. I said I understand, but I didn't say I would definitely bring the child over. It's ridiculous. If she wants to make things difficult for me, it's just the old saying about a great-grandmother-in-law testing her granddaughter-in-law. Even if I have a thousand grievances, outsiders would think I should endure it. But as an elder, tormenting a little baby? I would never agree to that. If she dares to say that the child should be brought to her while asleep, I'll immediately send a letter to Li Cheng."

"Young Princess, how dare you call the little prince by his name?" Nanny Nan was startled.

Huiyin snorted coldly.

Grand Dowager Wu, of course, wanted to see her grandson more often. As for wind and rain or the early hour, these were not considerations for her.

When she saw Huiyin come alone, she was somewhat angry. "Why didn't you bring Jing'er over? Didn't I tell you to bring him here?"

Huiyin replied calmly, "Grandmother, you know that Jing'er is only three months old and too young to be exposed to the wind. He hasn't woken up yet. I thought you would be considerate, so I didn't bring him over."

"You..." Grand Dowager Wu realized she had been outwitted by Huiyin.

"You have disobeyed your elder several times. Kneel down."

Huiyin looked at her in disbelief. When Grand Dowager Wu pointed at her, Huiyin, who had only thought the old lady was muddle-headed and had ignored the matter of Xun Rou, realized how muddle-headed the old lady was to demand that she kneel, disregarding all propriety.

But she wouldn't confront her directly. Otherwise, being in the right would turn into being in the wrong.

So, Huiyin said, confused, "Grandmother, what do you mean? Just because you want to see the child, should I disregard the fact that he is only a hundred days old and that the journey would be too taxing? Now, because I'm afraid the child might catch a cold, you want to humiliate me?"

Nanny Fan was afraid things would escalate and quickly stepped in to mediate. "Dowager, your health is not good. Let me help you inside to rest."

"No, make her kneel before me. Have you ever seen a granddaughter-in-law argue with her mother-in-law?" Grand Dowager Wu had never been challenged before.

Huiyin thought that if she knelt today, she would write her name backward in the future. She cried out, "Heaven help me, Grandmother is trying to ruin me!"

She rushed toward a pillar as if to bash into it, but the servants held her back. She still struggled to crash into the pillar and fainted. Before losing consciousness, she signaled to Qiu Feng.

Why was Huiyin looking at Qiu Feng? It was because Qiu Feng had been known for her dramatic wailing in the past.

Qiu Feng’s voice, always sharp and resonant, broke into a fresh wave of sobs: "My lady! You traveled all the way from Jizhou to marry into this family, and after nearly dying to give birth to the heir, they now want to force you to your death! Heaven, have mercy on our young princess! Young Prince, please come back and look after our princess!"

Nanny Nan, meanwhile, was organizing the sedan chairs with the others.

Elderly Dowager Wu was both frightened and furious. She felt that Huiyin had disobeyed her too many times, which made her lose face. She wanted to teach this daughter-in-law a lesson. If Huiyin were to kneel down, whether she was in the wrong or not would no longer matter; kneeling itself would be her punishment.

Unexpectedly, Princess Zheng was so fierce that she not only resisted but also screamed loudly. Elderly Dowager Wu, both anxious and angry, said to Nanny Fan, "Stop that girl from wailing. What nonsense is she saying? Go and slap her mouth."

Nanny Fan, however, found herself at a loss. "You made this mess," she thought, "and now you expect me to clean it up by offending others?"

Although most of the people in the mansion were Elderly Dowager Wu’s, some still quietly criticized Huiyin behind her back. However, Huiyin wasn’t someone to be trifled with. She had her own plans and wouldn’t tolerate humiliation. So, she feigned illness and discreetly spread the word, ensuring everyone knew what was happening without directly confronting Elderly Dowager Wu.

She even stayed in bed and refused to get up.

Word of the incident quickly reached the Prince of Wei’s Mansion. Wei Imperial Consort then invited Elderly Dowager Wu for a private discussion. Although there were many issues in Wei Imperial Consort’s own household—rivalries between wives and concubines, the Prince of Wei’s favoritism for Consort Xu, and the heir not yet being decided—she was clever enough not to mention these troubles to Elderly Dowager Wu. Elderly Dowager Wu, however, always felt the need to take the upper hand in front of others, so she said to Wei Imperial Consort, "My daughter-in-law is so disrespectful. Sister, I truly envy you for having such sensible and obedient daughters-in-law. Mine, on the other hand, is always threatening to die. She disobeys me, yet it’s somehow my fault."

"Dear sister, don’t be angry. If you don’t mind, I can help talk to her," Wei Imperial Consort comforted Elderly Dowager Wu, seeing her distress.

Elderly Dowager Wu said, "If I don’t speak out, who knows what rumors will spread outside."

As the two imperial consorts talked, it was time for lunch. Princess Wei arrived with Yin Lifang to attend to them. Yin Lifang had crafted a pair of knee pads for each of them. Made from soft white fox fur, they were both warm and smooth, fitting snugly around the knees. For Wei Imperial Consort, who was still relatively young, the pads featured a vibrant red ‘longevity’ character embroidered at the bottom, surrounded by blooming peonies. For Elderly Dowager Wu, the design was more traditional, with a Ruyi longevity pattern and embroidered pine and cypress, symbolizing long life and prosperity.

"These embroideries are truly exquisite," Elderly Dowager Wu said enviously.

Why were other people’s daughters-in-law so wonderful? Her fate was truly bitter.

Yin Lifang, however, didn’t care much. For her, these embroideries were just a way to pass the time. She even thought Elderly Dowager Wu was quite unreasonable. Huiyin, having the Prince of Wei’s only son, was now being forced to kneel or even die. While people wouldn’t say anything out of respect for Elderly Dowager Wu’s age and status, who wasn’t secretly gossiping about it?

In fact, what Elderly Dowager Wu considered public condemnation of Huiyin was of no concern to Huiyin herself. After the incident, she continued her daily greetings as if nothing had happened, but Elderly Dowager Wu didn’t dare ask her to bring the child over again. Later, Huiyin was also invited to the Prince of Wei’s Mansion to appreciate chrysanthemums.

Seeing Huiyin and Elderly Dowager Wu standing apart, Wei Imperial Consort said to Huiyin, "You should help your great-grandmother a little."

Huiyin smiled politely but deliberately, replying to Wei Imperial Consort, "Thanks to you, we are able to appreciate such beautiful chrysanthemums after returning from Xuzhou."

Wei Imperial Consort, hearing this, pretended not to hear and decided to ignore it, but she couldn’t help but feel that Princess Zheng’s temper was somewhat rebellious. Huiyin had done it intentionally because, in her eyes, Elderly Dowager Wu was a foolish person who spoke nonsense, while Wei Imperial Consort often stirred up trouble. If it weren’t for Wei Imperial Consort’s letter, she wouldn’t have come to Jianye with her child. This person had a Buddha-like face but a venomous heart, so it was better to keep a respectful distance.

Even if she explained the situation clearly, Elderly Dowager Wu wouldn’t listen to her.

Although Elderly Dowager Wu claimed to be devoted to Buddhism, she loved talking with Wei Imperial Consort. She often visited, and Huiyin eventually stopped pretending, not going to the Prince of Wei’s Mansion for almost half a month.

However, after Huiyin’s outburst, Elderly Dowager Wu didn’t dare push too far, only making snide remarks occasionally.

Like now, when Huiyin came to pay her respects, Elderly Dowager Wu held up a headband and said, "Look at this. It was given to me by Consort Yin. They are truly filial."

"Yes, in the Prince of Wei’s Mansion, the mother-in-law is kind, and the daughters-in-law are obedient. They are especially loving to their grandchildren. The last time Elderly Madame Huo celebrated her birthday, Wei Imperial Consort didn’t allow the Princess to bring the eldest princess back to her natal family, afraid she might catch a cold. But in our mansion, with you in charge, we just need to be filial to you," Huiyin said with a smile.

Elderly Dowager Wu understood the underlying meaning in Huiyin’s words: as an elder, if you don’t set an example of respect, how can you expect the younger generation to honor you with filial piety?

Elderly Dowager Wu, however, seethed with frustration over Huiyin’s defiance. She had letter after letter sent to Li Cheng in Xuzhou, urging him to come to Jianye and discipline Huiyin.

However, Huiyin never wrote a single letter to Li Cheng. The only letter she wrote was to her parents, to be delivered via Jiang Bipbo’s trade caravan in Jizhou.

She knew that any letter to her parents would first be reviewed by Li Cheng. This wasn’t because Li Cheng was nosy, but because their marriage was a strategic alliance. Any leaked information could have serious consequences for both Xuzhou and Jiangnan. If she wrote directly to Li Cheng, both her and Elderly Dowager Wu’s letters would end up being a he-said-she-said situation, and given Elderly Dowager Wu’s seniority, Li Cheng might side with her and fault Huiyin for not being more accommodating.

She wrote to her in-laws, sharing these matters to build a good reputation for herself.

As expected, Li Cheng had someone intercept Huiyin's letter and read it first. The letter began with greetings to her in-laws in Jizhou, followed by a litany of grievances. She mentioned that the child had started vomiting milk soon after arriving in Jianye and that Grand Dowager Wu had not visited them even once. To avoid gossip, Grand Dowager Wu gave her a pair of bracelets. Huiyin also wrote that the Grand Dowager wanted to take the child away and had asked her to go for morning greetings on a windy autumn day. Huiyin refused to go because the wind was too strong, which angered the Grand Dowager. The latter then forced her to kneel and kowtow in front of all the servants, humiliating her. In her distress, Huiyin considered killing herself by running into a pillar but decided against it at the last moment, thinking that she couldn't die in vain since heaven had given her life. Instead, she frightened Grand Dowager Wu a little.

Reading this, Li Cheng smiled. This was the Huiyin he knew, someone who wouldn't let others trample over her. He continued reading as Huiyin mentioned that she had few friends in Jianye and that most of the household staff were Grand Dowager Wu's people, who often bullied her. She concluded by saying that she longed to return to Jizhou and that her complaints were not to be taken too seriously by Lady Zheng.

For a moment, Li Cheng felt like a terrible person. His wife and child were suffering in the inner household. Grand Dowager Wu's letters only complained about Huiyin's lack of respect but never provided specific instances of disrespect.

Poor Huiyin! He needed to rescue his wife and child as soon as possible.

Grand Dowager Wu knew nothing of Huiyin's plans. Meanwhile, in Jianye, Yin Liying had brought Lord Xie back, whose poison injuries had greatly improved. The Prince of Wei did not blame him for losing the battle but was upset that Qingzhou had been taken again, with the loss of soldiers and resources. For now, Xie Jiuyi was no longer under consideration.

Huiyin also prepared lavish gifts for her visit to the Xie family. When she went, she happened to meet Yin Lifang, and the three women started chatting.

Interestingly, Yin Lifang and Yin Liying, despite being sisters, didn't look very similar and had completely different personalities. Huiyin had first interacted with Yin Liying, who was extremely beautiful but acted rashly, often without thinking things through and not always following proper etiquette. Yin Lifang, on the other hand, was much smarter and more composed. Huiyin had met Consort Xu a few times and found her too pretentious.

Yin Lifang initiated the conversation, "How is the young prince? Our Jing'er has been asking to see your heir ever since he saw him."

"He's doing well now, but I've been smelling something like burning charcoal lately. I wonder if any of you have noticed it," Huiyin casually mentioned. She knew the reason—because of the exhaustion from caring for the child, she was starting to imagine smells due to fatigue.

Yin Lifang could relate. "I went through something similar when I was pregnant with my son. I felt unwell for about a month and kept smelling burnt grass. Once I relaxed a bit, it got better."

Yin Lifang wasn't seductive or showy like Yin Liying, who always flaunted her relationship with Li Cheng. Yin Lifang spoke appropriately and could make people feel fond of her with just a few words.

Huiyin smiled and nodded in agreement.

Yin Liying also mentioned that she had ridden to Qingzhou but had to turn back before reaching it because Lord Xie had already headed to Jianye. Fortunately, the couple reunited in time.

After some conversation, Huiyin prepared to leave, and so did Yin Lifang.

"I have to rush back because my child is too young. You can stay longer and catch up with Lady Xie if you'd like," Huiyin suggested, seeming to get along well with Yin Lifang.

Yin Lifang honestly replied, "I have to go back early because the Dowager is attending a theater performance, and the Princess needs me there."

With that, Huiyin didn't say more.

After they left, Yin Liying said to her maid, Qiaozhen, "Did you notice that my sister gets along quite well with Princess Zheng? I feel like Princess Zheng can be quite cold and distant, and we don't always see eye to eye."

"Well, Miss Yin has always been like that," Qiaozhen replied cautiously. At first, everyone seemed to like her because she was pretty, carefree, and enthusiastic, but in the end, they all ended up preferring her older sister.

Yin Liying didn't get angry. She rested her head on her hand and looked at Qiaozhen. "I was worried before, but now I'm not worried about anything."

Qiaozhen advised, "You should take care of yourself. Last time, you had a miscarriage and didn't properly recover before running off again. Your health..."

"Alright, alright. I'll listen to you, okay?" Yin Liying also felt that her health wasn't as good as before.

Another person in confinement was Lü Xiao. She had been pregnant but miscarried after a fall. Lü Xiao was devastated and stayed in bed, constantly feeling chilled, even wearing socks. Grape brought her a cup of hot tea. "Crown Princess, please drink some hot tea. The imperial doctor said that your pregnancy was unstable from the beginning. With the Crown Prince's favor, you'll definitely have another child."

The Crown Prince was indeed very good to her, even neglecting his previous consort, Zheng Liangdi.

Just as she thought about it, she was told that Zheng Liangdi had arrived. Grape, feeling annoyed, said, "You're in recovery. What does she want?"

"Don't say that. When she was favored, she never reduced her interactions with me," Lü Xiao replied, not wanting to offend Zheng Deyin.

When Zheng Deyin entered and saw Lü Xiao's pale face and colorless lips, she felt a pang of guilt. Li Heng had told her that he had courted the Lü family for the great cause and that Lü Xiao's miscarriage had been influenced by them. The Crown Prince wanted the child to be born to someone else, rather than Lü Xiao, for the good of the realm.

"So, De Yin said quite a bit here: 'I am merely managing the Eastern Palace on your behalf for a few days. Once you have recovered, I will return the authority to you.'

Lu Xiao gave a weak smile. 'Zheng Liangdi, you’ve always been so good at managing the household. I’m not cut out for it. You should keep handling it.'

De Yin felt guilty again and thought, 'In the future, once I have a child, I will certainly treat you well.'

This time, without the Zheng family, the Eastern Palace was still the rightful ruler, reclaiming Qingzhou as in her past life. This showed that history remained unchanged. Li Cheng would eventually die. In this life, she also planned to bring Huiyin back from the south of the Yangtze as a way to make amends.

**

After jumping rope yesterday, her back and waist were aching today. Huiyin held her waist and went back to lie on the bed, picking up a book to read. Today, Grand Dowager Wu went to visit Wei Imperial Consort to chat about trivial matters. This gave her some leisure. Otherwise, the daily morning and evening greetings were exhausting. She was actually a lazy person and especially disliked serving others.

Moreover, if her letter were to be seen by Li Cheng, he would immediately come to fetch her back. There was no need for her to deal with this old woman.

Of course, Grand Dowager Wu went to chat with Wei Imperial Consort again, using the same old tricks. Wei Imperial Consort was also lonely. The troublesome matters in the Prince of Wei’s Mansion were nothing compared to the amusement of hearing about other families' gossip.

Furthermore, she could see that Princess Zheng was strong-willed and unyielding, unlike Grand Dowager Wu, who was easily swayed.

They spent the morning chatting, and at lunchtime, they heard that Li Cheng had come from Xuzhou, just after meeting with the Prince of Wei to report on military matters concerning Qing and Xuzhou. Wei Imperial Consort was delighted. 'It seems your grandson has come to support you.'

Grand Dowager Wu remained calm. 'What support? My grandson is filial and has surely come to visit me.'

The two of them were quite excited to finally see Li Cheng.

Naturally, Li Cheng would not create trouble in the Prince of Wei’s Mansion. He first pretended to be casual and paid his respects. 'Greetings to Grandmother and Wei Imperial Consort.'

'What brings you here from Xuzhou?' Wei Imperial Consort feigned asking.

Li Cheng replied, 'The court has withdrawn troops from Qingzhou. There are some military matters concerning Qing and Xuzhou that I need to report to Uncle Wei Wang.'

Wei Imperial Consort laughed. 'We don’t understand outside matters. Since you’re here, join us for lunch. We haven’t seen you in a long time.'

'Yes,' Li Cheng obliged, and accompanied them for the meal, even telling a few jokes, which made both imperial consorts laugh heartily.

This made Grand Dowager Wu even more convinced that her grandson was supporting her. She thought it would be best to take in more concubines and keep Princess Zheng confined to the cold, remote northern rooms, never to be favored. That would be her punishment for opposing her.

The more Grand Dowager Wu thought about it, the happier she became, and her expression revealed some of her thoughts.

Li Cheng glanced over and felt deeply troubled. Seeing his grandmother so happy, he knew she likely took pleasure in tormenting Huiyin. In Jianye, the people in the Prince of Wei’s Mansion must be siding with Grand Dowager Wu. Even the usually amiable Wei Imperial Consort would stand with Grand Dowager Wu. No wonder Huiyin felt isolated.

Huiyin was really too pitiful. Fortunately, he had come. Thinking of this, Li Cheng took a fierce bite out of the skewered lamb.

Seeing Li Cheng’s fierce expression, Grand Dowager Wu even proactively had someone pour wine for her grandson. 'Have some wine. With wine, your courage will grow. Let’s see how long Princess Zheng can hold out.'"

title: Chapter 36
content:
Chapter 36

After the meal, Li Cheng returned to the mansion with Grand Dowager Wu. They arrived quickly, and Li Cheng hurried forward to support Grand Dowager Wu. However, Grand Dowager Wu and Huiyin had long been at odds, despite maintaining the facade of a harmonious mother-in-law and daughter-in-law relationship in the past. Ever since Grand Dowager Wu had made Huiyin kneel, Huiyin had stopped coming to greet her every morning and evening, only showing up to go through the motions.

So, when they returned, Grand Dowager Wu deliberately did not inform Huiyin of their arrival, wanting to show Li Cheng how disobedient she was.

But she miscalculated. Upon returning, Li Cheng didn’t pay any attention to this and simply said, "She didn’t come over because she must be taking care of the child. Grandmother, let me see you to your room first, then I’ll go check on them."

Grand Dowager Wu had a lot to say but could only respond with, "Alright."

She thought it was best not to go herself, to avoid getting involved in any mess.

Unexpectedly, she was wrong. As soon as Li Cheng returned, he rushed to the main courtyard, taking the steps two at a time. He didn’t understand why, after just over a month of not seeing her, he had been thinking about her day and night. Now, standing in front of her door, he hesitated, feeling nervous about seeing her again.

Huiyin had just gotten up from the bed, having napped after tiring from reading. When she saw someone at the door, she thought she was mistaken.

"Prince..." she said, extremely delighted.

Li Cheng was immediately pleased by her joy, but then Huiyin’s expression changed, and she turned and walked back into the room. Li Cheng quickly followed her, and the servants scattered like startled birds.

He could tell she was upset and quickly said, "I’ve been thinking about you. I rushed back as fast as I could."

"Thinking of me? I bet you’re here to scold me. I’ve already heard that the Grand Dowager asked you to come back to scold me. If you lay a finger on me, I swear I’ll go back to Jizhou," Huiyin said firmly, sitting on the edge of the bed.

Li Cheng laughed. "Nonsense, I came back specifically to see you. Also, I’ll be staying in Jianye from now on. Prince of Wei told me that it would be convenient for me to travel between here and Xuzhou."

Hearing this, Huiyin felt troubled. She had only wanted Li Cheng to come back to help deal with Grand Dowager Wu, not to give up his military power.

So, she said anxiously, "Is Prince of Wei asking someone else to reap the rewards of your hard work? You’ve worked so hard to get Xuzhou in order, and now you’re just going to hand it over?"

Li Cheng placed his hands on her shoulders, trying to calm her down. "No, it’s still under my control. It’s quite fast to travel by boat from Jianye to Xuzhou. Don’t worry. It’ll be the same as before. I’ll come back to Jianye whenever I have time."

Only then did Huiyin feel relieved, but she thought that being under Prince of Wei’s watchful eye wasn’t necessarily a good thing. However, saying that would be stirring up trouble, so she just happily said, "Come on, let’s go see our son."

"He can see me anytime. What’s important is you. When I’m not by your side, has anyone been bullying you?" Li Cheng asked.

Huiyin hesitated for a moment and shook her head. "No, no one has bullied me. Oh, there’s just one thing. Lady Xie wanted me to give her a letter of introduction to Jizhou, but I didn’t dare take responsibility, so I didn’t give it to her."

"That’s why. If she doesn’t get a letter from Prince of Wei, I won’t send anyone to escort her either. She’s related to Prince of Wei through marriage, and Xie Jiuyi and I are close friends," Li Cheng explained with a smile.

Huiyin let out a sigh of relief. "But I don’t have a good relationship with them. I don’t have many friends here."

In fact, Huiyin didn’t care much about friends. When dealing with men, she knew one trick that always worked: if he likes you and cares about you, he’ll always have your best interests at heart.

"Aren’t I your friend? Besides, friends are rare and precious. You’re so young and of such high status that most people can’t be your friend. When I’m not here, you’re always so formal and don’t go out much. If you want to host flower or tea parties, I fully support you," Li Cheng said with concern.

Huiyin shook her head. "With Grandmother managing the household, it’s not proper for me to host such events."

Li Cheng took her hand, looking surprised. "Grandmother is still managing the household? She’s so old; she should be sharing the burden with you."

Huiyin fell silent, and Li Cheng understood. It was Grand Dowager Wu’s issue. As she grew older, her grip on power became tighter. The corruption below was just a reflection of the leadership above. Grand Dowager Wu held onto the household management not just for money but for power, to remain superior.

Li Cheng didn’t agree with this. The Huaiyin Mansion should rightfully be controlled by the Princess of Huaiyin. These so-called dowagers were no longer funded by the court. Their expenses were covered by their own descendants. The reason the income from Xuzhou is low is that more than half of it goes to Jianye. They had to support Grand Dowager Wu and couldn’t be stingy. With the wealth inherited from his father, the Prince of Wu, and his mother from the prestigious Boling Cui family, Li Cheng had more than enough resources. He was still a commandery prince.

As Huiyin pointed out, if they could cut down on these expenses, they could put the money toward future military needs.

Although he is the nephew of the Prince of Wei, in a way, the Prince of Wu ranks second. The Prince of Wei is the youngest son of the late emperor. If the future emperor doesn't succeed or the crown prince can't control the situation, he, as royal blood, might still have a chance.

Before, when he had no son, it was different. Now that he has a wife and child, his thoughts have naturally changed.

Huiyin, having understood Li Cheng's words, knew her husband was a man of his word. With that in mind, she began to unbutton his clothes, "You rushed over so hurriedly, don't you miss me even a little?"

…

As for Grand Dowager Wu, she had someone wait at Huiyin's place for news. Of course, Nanny Fan wouldn't go. She knew all too well that getting involved in such matters never led to anything good. In the past, she had charged into battles only to end up being blamed. Grand Dowager Wu would just curse and complain, but in the end, there was no real benefit, not even extra rewards for herself.

This time, Liu Niang was sent to gather information. Liu Niang stood at the door for a long time. Although she couldn't hear what was being said inside, the fact that the servants had brought water in three times was telling enough.

Some servants, quite perceptive of the situation, like Nanny Fan, knew that although they were tied to Grand Dowager Wu, Princess Zheng was the legitimate princess and would eventually take charge of the household. It was better to make a good connection with her. On the other hand, there were servants like Liu Niang, who hoped to stir up discord between Grand Dowager Wu and Huiyin and profit from it.

So, when she returned to report to Grand Dowager Wu, she painted a vivid picture: "I saw the Little Prince storm in angrily, and then, for some reason, they started bringing water inside."

Grand Dowager Wu slammed the table, "Truly, lust clouds judgment."

Nanny Fan lowered her eyes, not wanting to speak, when Liu Niang added, "The Little Prince's travel gear was almost all brought back by Manager Qiao. It looks like he might be staying for a long time. You can't afford to be careless."

"I understand," said Grand Dowager Wu, feeling helpless. She wondered if her letter hadn't reached her grandson. If so, she would have to tell him in person later.

Liu Niang smiled again, "Actually, if you have no other way, I have another idea."

Grand Dowager Wu looked at her, "Oh, do tell."

Liu Niang then whispered into Grand Dowager Wu's ear. Nanny Fan didn’t hear what was said, but not hearing it was probably for the best; it meant she wouldn’t have to deal with it.

After spending the afternoon in playful intimacy, when Huiyin and Li Cheng got up, Li Cheng looked refreshed, while Huiyin's face was flushed. It must be said, Li Cheng was quite impressive in every way.

"It's almost time for dinner with Grand Dowager Wu. I need to attend to her. If you hadn't come today, there would have been a feast to welcome you." Huiyin fastened her clothes.

Li Cheng smiled and helped her up, "Let's go together. Don't worry, with me here, you'll still be in charge of the household."

Huiyin shook her head, "No, don't offend your grandmother for my sake. It wouldn't be good to be labeled as unfilial."

"It won't happen. She will still need to rely on me in the future. Even now, the reason why the Wei Imperial Consort and others here show her respect is because of me." Li Cheng was very clear-headed. He was filial, but not blindly so.

Huiyin then said to Li Cheng, "These household matters are trivial. I actually have something important to discuss with you. Last time, the gift you sent to Second Imperial Consort Yin was quite generous, right? But when I visited their residence, I found out that the person most favored by the Prince of Wei is actually Second Imperial Consort Xu. The eldest son of Second Imperial Consort Yin hasn't been granted the title of crown prince yet."

Li Cheng paused as he helped her up, "But the eldest son is still the eldest son."

Huiyin smiled, "I think if the crown prince isn't decided, people's hearts will be unsettled. My lord, I know you've always been loyal to the Prince of Wei. But with the world in turmoil, it's not just heroes who shape the times; it's also the times that shape heroes. Lü Wei is arrogant and self-centered, seeing no one else. The He family is the same. My father is brave but lacks strategy. The only truly capable person is Wei Duo. My lord, why not rise with the tide?"

"Nonsense, we're not discussing this again," Li Cheng's expression changed.

Huiyin thought that any man, especially one who commands troops, like Li Cheng, who is quite strategic and capable, would be tempted, even if he didn't want to admit his desires for now. So, she didn't push further and just smiled, "Alright, alright, I won't say any more."

After they went out, they first visited Jing'er. Seeing his chubby little hand, Li Cheng's heart softened even more. Jing'er was awake and a cheerful child. When Li Cheng held his hand, he giggled.

Hearing the child's laughter lifted the adults' spirits.

When they went to see Grand Dowager Wu, she wouldn't directly criticize Huiyin in front of her. Huiyin also stood up attentively to serve her. As a former Empress Dowager, having to serve this muddled old woman, she was unwilling in her heart, but there was no other way unless she truly took power herself.

The night passed without incident. The next morning, Grand Dowager Wu didn't expect Li Cheng to come over first.

The day before, although she saw that Li Cheng and Princess Zheng didn’t exchange many words, the affection between them was clear from their shared tender looks. She had wanted to secretly speak ill of Princess Zheng to Li Cheng, but his decision to stay in Jianye had distracted her.

"Greetings, Grandmother," Li Cheng smiled.

Grand Dowager Wu looked at him lovingly. "You've been travel-weary; you should take care of yourself. Why did you come so early this morning?"

Li Cheng replied, "My wife was supposed to come, but I have something to discuss with you. As I mentioned yesterday, I plan to settle in Jianye from now on, so I intend to host a banquet at the estate for Uncle Wei Wang and others as a way to thank them for taking care of you, Grandmother, all these years."

"That is only proper," Grand Dowager Wu said with a smile.

Li Cheng continued, "Although Princess Zheng is young, she has been excellent at managing the household affairs in Xuzhou for me. Yesterday, I saw that you are still in charge of the household. I scolded her for it. You are getting on in years, and she is still young and inexperienced. How can I let you, at your age, continue to manage things for me?"

Grand Dowager Wu stiffened and pointed at Li Cheng. "You! Are you trying to force me to hand over the household management?"

In truth, since his parents had passed away, Li Cheng had spent most of his time outside dealing with affairs and had never really interacted much with Grand Dowager Wu. He thought he had been tactful, perhaps even more so than when speaking to his wife. He hadn't expected Grand Dowager Wu's reaction to be so baffling.

"Grandmother, what are you saying? Is it you who wants to keep the household management? Then it is my fault." Li Cheng thought that even if people had such thoughts in their hearts, they shouldn't say them out loud. After all, even those who are chosen to be emperor go through the ritual of declining the honor three times before accepting.

But he still knelt down to go through the motions.

Grand Dowager Wu also realized she had overreacted and helped Li Cheng to his feet. "Of course, I am not clinging to this household management, but your wife is too young. It's hard for her to gain respect. I didn't say this before, but she isn't just disrespectful to me. The issue is that she even quarreled with the Huo family over a merchant's daughter. She has also been disrespectful to Wei Imperial Consort, speaking sharply. In short, as long as she is around, everyone is unhappy. How can I not hold things together?"

Li Cheng, however, thought of his wife. Although she often spoke humbly, her demeanor was far from ordinary. Indeed, she had even encouraged him to seize power. She was no ordinary woman. He had scolded her on the surface, but in his heart, he was in turmoil.

She was no ordinary woman, but Huiyin was very reasonable. How could she be portrayed as a troublemaker? It's like trying to explain snow to someone who has never seen it.

So Li Cheng changed his approach. "Huiyin is, after all, the Princess of Huaiyin. As you said, she doesn't know many people, so she might have social issues. I thought that having you host flower and tea parties at home to broaden her social circle would help."

Grand Dowager Wu hadn't expected her grandson to be so considerate of Princess Zheng. Every word he said seemed to defend her and work in her favor. She wanted to bring up the idea that Nanny Liu had suggested, but she decided to keep quiet until things were more settled.

She simply said, "You've just returned, and now you want to host another banquet? I don't understand these things, so I'll leave it to Steward Qian to handle."

Li Cheng returned in defeat and told Huiyin about it. Huiyin consoled him, "This is only natural. Why do you think people strive to reach the top? It's because they don't want to be controlled by others. If the person in charge is reasonable and broad-minded, it's fine. But if they are mediocre and still like to give orders, who would willingly stay under them?"

"You're quite bold to say such things. No matter what, we must respect our grandmother," Li Cheng said, lacking conviction.

Huiyin stood up. "Fine, I won't say anything more."

Before, the two of them would only talk about love, as they were alone in Xuzhou without any conflicts. Now, with his elders and external matters involved, these were crucial points of adjustment for the couple.

Seeing Huiyin like this, Li Cheng thought back to their time in Xuzhou. He remembered how she hadn't gotten upset when he revised the entire gift list, but now her temper seemed a bit sharper, though what she said made sense.

"Don't. If you don't tell me the truth, who will?" Li Cheng said with a smile.

Huiyin knew he was still young, only in his early twenties, and couldn't yet believe in the dream of uniting the world. Moreover, Li Cheng's execution was strong, indicating he was a pragmatic person. He always did what he could and never reached for things beyond his grasp.

Therefore, Huiyin said, "Don't try to get the household management for me. If Grandmother doesn't want me to manage it, I won't. I'm serious. As long as we can be together, I'm happy."

"No, I said I would help you get it back, and I will. Because I like you, I want to give you all the good things. Liking someone shouldn't mean letting them suffer." Li Cheng disagreed with Huiyin.

Liking someone shouldn't mean letting them suffer.

He suddenly stood up and rushed out. Nanny Nan came in from outside, confused. "Princess, Little Prince..."

"Let him be," Huiyin thought. Grand Dowager Wu was not always clear-headed and struggled to distinguish right from wrong or close from distant. Li Cheng had a tendency to be insistent.

Sure enough, soon after, Qiū Fēng ran over. "Princess, Little Prince has asked Steward Qian to report the accounts, and he has also summoned the four head accountants. It seems he is going to audit the books."

Huiyin tapped the table. "Here it comes." She didn't want to provoke Li Cheng unnecessarily. Grand Dowager Wu thought she could suppress others with her seniority, but she was mistaken. Li Cheng was not someone to be underestimated.

On the other side, Grand Dowager Wu was still doing her morning prayers when several servants rushed in to alert her. She stood up and said, "What's happening? Is he questioning my trustworthiness?"

The servants were just kowtowing, which made Grand Dowager Wu so upset that she sent Nanny Fan to relay a message. Nanny Fan was cursing inwardly, "Why do they only come to me when there’s trouble? Never for anything good!"

But as a servant, what could she do? She could only go and deliver the message.

Li Cheng, however, smiled and said, "Grandmother, what are you talking about? I am the Prince of Huaiyin, so of course I will look into the accounts of Huaiyin Mansion. There's no need for you to worry. I'm just here to check on the situation of the mansion. As the saying goes, the man takes care of external affairs while the woman manages internal affairs. How could I not check?"

Nanny Fan had no choice but to return and report Li Cheng's words to Grand Dowager Wu.

Grand Dowager Wu wanted to scold him again, but she found herself helpless. What could she possibly scold Li Cheng for? He was her backbone. If he really wasn't up to par, even the fiefdom of Huaiyin might be lost. Wouldn't she then be living under someone else's roof? Moreover, this mansion indeed belonged to Li Cheng.

Li Cheng was certainly not just eating the rice of idleness. From a young age, he had learned how to manage the Prince of Wu's Mansion alongside the Prince of Wu. Later, when he joined the Prince of Wei, the first task the Prince of Wei assigned him was not to lead troops but to manage the Prince of Wei’s Mansion.

As he went through these account books, he couldn't help but wonder how confident the steward of Huaiyin Mansion must have been, thinking that no one would check the accounts. The books were a mess, with random scribbles.

He couldn't help but address Steward Qian, "My grandmother never hosts any banquets, and we don’t often exchange gifts or formal courtesies. So how is it that the silver I allocated has already shown a deficit? I need you to carefully recalculate the remaining silver."

Steward Qian, being a chief steward, first glanced at Li Cheng before trying to clear his name. "Little Prince, we didn't embezzle anything. Some of the remaining silver was handed over to the Dowager. This year, the Dowager donated 20,000 taels of silver to the four renowned temples."

"Wait, which four temples did you donate to, and when? I'll send someone to check on horseback right away. You'd better tell me the truth; otherwise, I won't spare you from punishment."

"Yes, it was to Datuo Temple, Puji Temple, Guanghong Temple, and Longkong Temple," replied Steward Qian. Although he had indeed embezzled a little here and there, it was only petty cash. He certainly hadn't taken any large sums.

Li Cheng first sent people to investigate, and then he had Steward Qian and several accountants lead him to check the mansion's storerooms. To his surprise, this year, the storeroom for rewards had only about one-third of its contents left.

"Tell me, where did all these things go? Don't try to deceive me, or I won't be polite."

Steward Qian had no choice but to kneel and confess the truth. He had embezzled 5,000 taels, and half of the items in the mansion's storeroom had been sold off by him. The other four accountants together had embezzled another 5,000 taels.

One of them even admitted to falsifying accounts, saying that out of the 5,000 taels donated to Puji Temple, 1,000 taels had been embezzled by him.

"Good, good, good. So, you're all a bunch of parasites. That's already 30,000 taels. And what about my rice allocations? When my father, the king, was enfeoffed in the Jiangnan region, he was granted 1,352 qing of reclaimed lakebed land and 10,000 qing of manor land. After my father passed away, 400 qing were allocated to my uncle, the Prince of Wei, and the rest was inherited by me. So why is it that now, there's only old rice left, and the new rice is so scarce? How have you been managing this household for me?"

Li Cheng was so enraged that he nearly unsheathed his sword and executed them right there.

Steward Qian was so scared that he soaked his pants in fear and collapsed on the floor. Normally, Li Cheng would have gagged him and taken him away for a beating, but since Grand Dowager Wu had been managing the household for several years, he decided to confront her directly instead. "Tell me the truth."

"Yes, it was the Dowager who ordered us to sell the items. She kept the old rice for the people in the mansion and reserved the new rice and the japonica rice from the imperial estate for herself. The rest was all sold because the Dowager was afraid it would get infested if left for too long." After saying this, Steward Qian lowered his head and remained silent.

Li Cheng sneered, "Since the Dowager is old, you're all shifting the blame onto her. Fine, say that in front of her. Come, bring the Dowager here."

If Grand Dowager Wu didn't care about her dignity, then he wouldn't spare her either.

The message quickly reached Grand Dowager Wu, who immediately became alarmed. "How could I possibly confront a servant? Family matters should be handled within the family… He should have beaten Steward Qian to death on the spot."

Nanny Fan also hurriedly asked, "What should we do, Dowager?"

"Say that I am unwell and unable to come. In the past, all household matters were entrusted to Steward Qian. I know nothing about anything else." After saying this, Grand Dowager Wu feigned weakness, looking like she might collapse at any moment.

Nanny Fan relayed Grand Dowager Wu's words to the messenger Li Cheng had sent. Even the servant couldn't help but show a hint of contempt in their eyes.

Within two days, Huaiyin Mansion had replaced all its staff. Li Cheng forced Steward Qian and several accountants to return all the embezzled silver from over the years. Even Grand Dowager Wu pretended that she had been saving the money for Li Cheng. Li Cheng then handed all the money over to Huiyin and put her in charge of the household again.

Looking at the room full of silver, Huiyin signaled for Li Cheng to calm down. "I understand now. Money and power go hand in hand with love. Take a seat and relax."
