Chapter 37

◎Combined Double Chapters◎

Li Cheng certainly couldn’t say that the Grand Dowager Wu had mismanaged the household, so outwardly he stated that the household servants of the Huaiyin Mansion had extorted and deceived the Grand Dowager, using these reasons to deal with them all.

Although it’s said that still water runs deep, on the other hand, if greed is not eliminated, it will harm those who are not greedy. These corrupt individuals—which one of them didn’t try to drag others down to shut them up?

After cleaning out so many people, Li Cheng had people dispatched from Xuzhou, leaving only a few to guard the mansion there. He had brought almost all the important matters with him this time.

Embarrassed by the massive corruption among her subordinates, the Grand Dowager Wu stayed home to fast and pray instead of going out. Huiyin, on the other hand, helped rebuild a Buddhist hall and converted a quiet residence in the mansion into a family nunnery, inviting several nuns to fill the space and claiming she was discussing Buddhist teachings with the Grand Dowager Wu.

These expenses, though only around one thousand taels of silver, earned her a good reputation, which was more valuable than the daily ritual of paying respects. After all, real gold and silver were spent, so no one could say anything.

It was also said that some servants from Xuzhou would come over, including Granny Chao and Yun Hui. However, Huiyin had almost arranged the staff here and didn’t want to employ Granny Chao and Yun Hui anymore, so she apologized to them: "Yun Hui, we didn’t know you were coming and had already prepared someone for the position. The only place currently lacking a steward is the Snow-Sleeping Nunnery."

Granny Chao spoke up for her daughter: "Young Princess, this doesn’t seem appropriate."

Huiyin smiled: "Mother, I’m doing this for your own good. The money steward and the four main accountants were caught embezzling funds, and somehow your name was implicated in the affair. I’m aware you are the wet nurse of the young prince, so I suppressed the matter. The prince’s eyes cannot tolerate sand, so I transferred your elder daughter to a quieter place. When the prince’s anger subsides, I’ll speak on your behalf."

Fearing they wouldn’t believe her, Huiyin said to Nanny Nan: "Bring over the statements made by the money steward and the private accounts recorded by his nephew for verification."

Granny Chao didn’t know that there had been a major overhaul in Jianye. Huiyin immediately presented the evidence to Yun Hui. It’s okay if you, Granny Chao, are illiterate; Yun Hui can read.

Yun Hui picked up the ledger and examined each entry, along with the fingerprints of the money steward. It stated that one hundred taels of silver were allocated for the young prince’s lamp oil, but less than two taels were actually used, with the remaining ninety-eight taels being offered as a tribute to Granny Chao. This was just one item; several others followed.

In fact, Yun Hui was well aware that anyone could be found at fault if investigated. They were using her mother and daughter to curry favor with Li Cheng.

Obviously, Yun Hui was more pragmatic than Granny Chao and immediately said: "We will do as the young princess says."

"It’s not just what I say; I’ve saved your lives," Huiyin didn’t mind. She didn’t like factionalism and acknowledged that Yun Hui had certain abilities and was fair and impartial. Therefore, she had given her a chance. However, this person not only met secretly with Yin Liyi outside in Xuzhou, speaking ill of her behind her back, but Huiyin also received a letter from Xuzhou stating that Yun Hui had put on makeup, hoping to seduce the young prince.

With all these accumulated incidents, if she didn’t address them, would Zheng Huiyin be nothing more than a figurehead?!

Granny Chao almost fell to the ground, and Huiyin coldly looked at her: "If you want to cause a scene, go ahead, but don’t disgrace your family."

Previously, no matter how Granny Chao treated Huiyin, she wasn’t afraid because she was the wet nurse. The Grand Dowager and her group were still around, and the princess was just an outsider and a young daughter-in-law. Now, she had been brought down.

After dealing with Granny Chao and her daughter, Yun Hui, she promoted the son of Nanny Fan to be the second steward. Nanny Fan became even more open and honest with Huiyin.

Even the previously cunning Liu Niang was reported by Nanny Fan, and Huiyin dealt with her directly.

But she also uncovered from Liu Niang the suggestion made to the Grand Dowager Wu, which was to have Li Cheng marry the younger sister of the wife of the Prince of Wei from the Huo family. This was indeed hard to refuse. Although Li Cheng and the Prince of Wei were of different generations, it didn’t matter to the Huo family. Becoming a secondary consort would still provide status and could enhance the relationship between the Prince of Wei and Li Cheng.

"I plan to hold a flower banquet when the first snow falls. If the green plum blossoms bloom, it will add an elegant touch." Huiyin decided to suppress these matters for now and actively expand her network in Jianye.

In the past, whenever she relied on men’s connections or achieved success through them, she always worried that people would question her authenticity. Later, she realized why Li Cheng stood up for her. Besides liking her, he also acknowledged her abilities and talents, which were her own strengths. Moreover, when men rely on others, they can be even more stubborn than women.

To be honest, there are many people who are not up to their positions, but at least she has proven herself worthy of hers.

Li Cheng had no objections: "This is naturally very good, and you can arrange all of these."

"Well, our Jing’er will soon be six months old, and you’ve been here for two months. I wonder if we’ll be able to spend the New Year in Jianye this year?" Huiyin asked.

Li Cheng smiled: "That’s not something I can decide. Anyway, I’ll be at the mansion when I’m free. By the way, the weather is turning cold, and Uncle Prince of Wei is preparing for a hunt. You ladies can also join us for some relaxation."

Huiyin was delighted to hear this, and when she went to pay her respects to the Wei Imperial Consort and the Princess, they also mentioned this matter.

The Princess of Wei smiled: "We thought, coming from the north, you must be skilled at horseback riding. We women of Jiangzuo, the eastern region known for its sword dancers, can also show off our skills. We can all have fun together then."

"Although I am in Jizhou, my horse riding skills are mediocre. I still want to ask Aunt Wu, what kind of items should we bring?" Huiyin felt that ever since the Grand Dowager Wu began to "devote herself to Buddhism," her relationship with the Prince of Wei's mansion had grown closer.

In the past, they were very familiar with the Grand Dowager Wu. Even now, they praise her in front of me. Do they really not know what kind of person she is? No, it's just plain annoying. Don't think only the old men and women at the village entrance like to stir up trouble and use others to their ends. Underneath all that refinement, the noble royals are no different from anyone else.

Huiyin once had great admiration for the Eastern Palace, but later realized it was nothing special. Once you demystify authority, you begin to judge it objectively.

The Princess of Wei mentioned many things, and the Grand Dowager Wei asked about the Grand Dowager Wu: "How has my old sister been these days? I've been wondering why she hasn't come."

"When we hold a banquet at home, we will definitely invite you and Aunt Wu to come over and meet Grand Dowager Wu. She spends her days discussing Buddhism with the nuns at Woxue Nunnery, and even our young prince is rarely seen," Huiyin said.

The Princess of Wei knew she was making things up. The Grand Dowager Wu used to be full of resentment when she was in the palace and couldn't keep her mouth shut. She couldn't go a day without gossiping. The idea that she is now devoted to Buddhist studies is clearly nonsense. But she couldn't expose her; after all, the Grand Dowager Wu was from the Huaiyin Mansion.

So, the Grand Dowager Wei only said, "Very good."

After paying her respects to the Grand Dowager Wei, Huiyin went to visit the Princess of Wei alone. There, the Princess's eldest daughter, Princess Jianjia, was writing nearby. The young princess, though not very old, held herself high due to being the legitimate daughter of the principal wife. This isn't to say she was bad. Huiyin judged a person by their environment. Except for a few individuals who were completely unaffected by their surroundings, most people were shaped by their surroundings.

This Princess of Wei appeared to be a composed matriarch, but inside, she must be anxious. After all, without a son, the position of heir would fall to someone else, which was why the princess was so sensitive.

It wasn't that Huiyin loved to judge others, but she believed that knowing your enemies and allies leads to victory. These people could be allies or rivals, so she needed to keep a close eye on them.

"Royal sister-in-law," Princess Jianjia came over to greet her.

Huiyin smiled and took her hand, "I haven't seen you for a few days, and you seem to have grown even more graceful. I heard from your mother that you're now studying the Four Books; it's great that reading really helps you understand things better. By the way, I brought some Yulu Tuan and Touhua Ci from our mansion. You can take a break while writing and have some snacks."

"Thank you, Royal sister-in-law," the princess replied with a smile.

The Princess of Wei had her wet nurse take her away to have some snacks and then, appearing to open her heart, said, "I understand the situation in your mansion. However, since our Dowager and your Dowager are close, I don't feel it's appropriate to say anything."

This was a gesture of goodwill. If Huiyin were only nineteen years old, she would have been deeply grateful. But now, she only expressed gratitude on the surface, "I have always known how much you care for me. I have already told our young prince about your kindness. He said that when he was at the Prince of Wei's mansion, everything depended on your care."

"It's nothing special. It's only natural. I can't manage the affairs of the men outside, but we women, especially with our close relationship, mustn't become estranged and become a joke to outsiders. To be honest, I envy you. I have to constantly take medicinal potions," the Princess of Wei was actually showing her vulnerability. This method was the best way to shorten the distance between people. When someone usually high and mighty shares their troubles with you, it doesn't feel fake.

Who knows what will happen to the whole of China in the future? But at present, even noble ladies, if they don't have sons, seem to be at a disadvantage.

There were many things Huiyin could brush off, but not this one. She couldn't help much in this matter, "Royal Aunt, you are still young."

The Princess of Wei waved her hand, "If I were able to have children, I would have by now. Look at how fortunate you are to have given birth as soon as you entered the household."

Huiyin quickly said, "It's not much fortune. They say life is either a struggle followed by success or a smooth start followed by challenges. Royal Aunt, as a noble princess, you have such a sensible eldest princess. As the saying goes, flowers bloom before bearing fruit. You will definitely have a young prince in the future. Don't worry."

"Your words have certainly made me feel much lighter," the Princess of Wei said.

The two chatted for a few more moments until Su Mama, who was by the Princess of Wei's side, came in and said, "Madam, the wife of Yin Recorder has come to pay her respects."

The Princess of Wei explained to Huiyin, "This is the mother of Consort Yin. They live not far from us."

Huiyin thought that since Consort Yin had already given birth to the Prince of Wei's eldest son, why was her father still just a recorder? She voiced this thought.

Su Mama, who was by the Princess of Wei's side, smiled and said, "What is the young princess saying? Our princess has mentioned this to the prince before, but Consort Yin firmly refused. She said she knew her father's abilities, and if he were given a position too high, it would not be a blessing but a disaster for him. So, the prince only gave some monetary rewards to their family, allowing the Yin family to buy their current residence."

"So that's how it is," Huiyin thought. This Consort Yin is quite clear-headed. It seems she is not someone who suffers unnecessarily. It's likely that Yin Recorder truly lacks ability.

This reminded her of her own experiences. In her previous life, her father was good at military strategy but lacked cunning, often leaving himself isolated without reinforcements. If she hadn't poisoned Li Heng in the end, Wei Duo would have targeted the Zheng family.

Soon, a beautiful woman entered, accompanied by a rather delicate young girl, about thirteen or fourteen years old. The girl was graceful in appearance and manner.

Su Mama was quietly introducing, "Madam Yin, this is our Huaiyin Princess."

Madam Yin bowed and said, "I pay my respects to the princess and the young princess."

"Please rise quickly, oh, why did you bring your niece along today?" Princess of Wei was clearly quite familiar with the Yin family.

Madam Yin sighed, "This child has been in mourning for her mother, who passed away. Her father died early, and her only brother has gone to Donglai. So, we brought her here and now consider her one of our own daughters."

Princess of Wei added that the child's father had once been a companion of Prince Wu, whose daughter had married into Princess Huiyin's family. Princess Huiyin then asked Nanny Nan to reward her with a pair of gold and silver ingots with crabapple blossom designs and said with concern, "Since you are an old friend, I hope Madam Yin will bring your third daughter to visit our residence soon."

Madam Yin looked up at Princess Huiyin and saw her wearing a peach-yellow satin robe with red and white floral embroidery. Princess Huiyin's appearance was exquisite and charming, and Madam Yin dared not meet her gaze, able only to stammer a reply.

Noticing Madam Yin's awkwardness, Princess of Wei had her leave after she finished paying her respects.

Princess Huiyin continued talking with Madam Yin, while Madam Yin and Yin Lifang happily struck up a conversation. Yin Lifang took her younger cousin's hand and said, "Since you're now part of our family, I'll treat you as my own sister."

"Big Sister," Yin Lijun had heard since childhood that she resembled her elder cousin, so she naturally felt affection towards Yin Lifang.

Noticing that her mother had something to say, Yin Lifang sent Yin Lijun off to tour the garden. Afterward, Madam Yin said, "Just now, I saw the Princess of Huaiyin, and she rewarded Lijun with a pair of ingots."

Yin Lifang paused, "Mother, let's not bring up the past. The princess now has a husband and child, and their marriage is quite good. It's best to let it go."

"Even so, the position of Princess of Huaiyin could have been yours. It was so close, just one step away. Princess Wu personally promised it, and I was overjoyed back then. But the couple died too early, and you were chosen by Prince Wei," Madam Yin said regretfully.

Madam Yin had always believed that Princess Wu favored her second daughter because she was pretty and lively, able to play well with boys, unlike her quiet and reserved elder daughter. Their family held a low-ranking position as recorders, but they relied on the childhood friendships between their children. Even becoming a secondary consort was difficult, yet Princess Wu had promised them the position of primary consort.

Yin Lifang looked around and said, "Mother, let's not talk about this. If Prince Wei were to hear, what would he think? Besides, we can't mention this in front of Liyi."

Madam Yin nodded, knowing that her elder daughter was always prudent. Mr. Li had previously taken care of the second daughter because of the elder daughter. Unexpectedly, Liyi had misunderstood and, favoring Xie Jiuyi, had distanced herself from Mr. Li.

After some casual conversation, Yin Lifang brought up matters of the household, "Prince Wei favors Consort Xu more, and originally, we had no conflicts. But after I gave birth to the eldest son and gained favor in the residence, she began stirring up trouble, to the point where even Princess Wei couldn't tolerate it."

Madam Yin felt deeply pained.

Yin Lifang then mentioned the upcoming hunting event, for which her son would also participate, requiring her to make early preparations. Consort Xu was pressing closely, and if her son were to inherit the position of prince, how could she allow her son to exist?

**

Half a month later, Princess Huiyin joined Li Cheng for the hunting event, leaving Nanny Nan and Fugui, her trusted confidants, behind, as she was most concerned about her son.

"Maybe I shouldn't go. The child is too young, and we just reorganized the residence. It wouldn't be good if someone with ill intentions took advantage of the situation." Whenever this thought arose, Princess Huiyin wished her natal family were nearby.

Li Cheng, hearing her concern, also felt uneasy but said, "Don't worry, I will leave people here in the residence."

But the couple was still worried and, looking at each other, Princess Huiyin said, "Why don't we bring the child along? It's just an extra carriage, and it's only a day or two away."

Rather than worrying about the child's discomfort during the journey, the couple feared potential harm. If Grand Dowager Wu were more reliable, it would be better, but she was the least dependable. Li Cheng agreed.

"Our boy is almost seven months old; it should be fine. He rarely even sneezes." Princess Huiyin was reluctant to leave her son, so she took great care in bringing him along.

Li Cheng told her about the participants in the hunting event, "Mostly local noble families from Jianye. Although their status is not as high as yours, as you know, these families have both wealth and talent, and I need those people."

Princess Huiyin held his arm and said, "I understand. You mean for me to control my temper, right? Got it."

"No, I mean if someone provokes you, you don't have to be straightforward. You’re a straightforward person." Li Cheng knew his wife was a straightforward northern lady, somewhat strong-willed. It was fine at home, but elsewhere, some people might scheme behind the scenes.

He remembered Yin Liyi had been schemed against, which he had discovered by chance. Those young ladies' methods were no less sophisticated than the boys'.

Princess Huiyin tilted her head and looked at him, "Thank you, I understand."

Then, she helped him hang a scented sachet, "Since giving birth to Jing'er and being busy with household matters, I finally made a scented sachet after so long."

Li Cheng looked at it, seeing the dark blue satin base with exquisite embroidery of rich and noble peonies. The sachet was primarily in blue and green, with jade beads attached to the cord, conveying both wealth and elegance.

"This scented sachet is embroidered so beautifully; let me smell what's inside." He undid it, put it to his nose, and it was not a pungent refreshing scent nor sandalwood, but a very pleasant fragrance. The sachet contained jasmine, osmanthus, rose, peppermint, and rosemary, creating a refreshing fragrance.

Huiyin explained, "This kind of fragrant pouch is perfect for use in the carriage. You know how it can start to smell stuffy and unpleasant if you sit inside for too long. So this pouch can dispel the bad odor and stuffiness."

She was the type to either go all in or not at all, and when she did something, she gave it her full attention. This was especially true for incense making—a skill she knew nothing about initially. But after being mocked at a social event, she began to study it intensely, even learning medicinal cuisine as part of her research into the art of incense.

Upon hearing this, Li Cheng liked it even more. When he saw Huiyin asking someone to bring flour, he asked in surprise, "Are you planning to make hand-pulled noodles for me? The kind you made for me in Xuzhou?"

Huiyin covered her mouth and laughed. "What? Do you think I don't value you enough?"

Li Cheng lowered his head and said, "I just feel like... the love you have for me isn't as much as the love I have for you."

"Don't be so calculating. We are a couple; we have a lifetime to love each other. Those who love desperately from the start, I find that rather fake."

A few words from her cheered Li Cheng up again.

On the day of the outing, the sky was clear and bright. Jing'er was getting stronger, and Huiyin felt like she could hardly hold him anymore. Fortunately, the road was wide enough. It took them a day's journey to reach the hunting grounds. The men, unable to wait any longer, eagerly rode off into the woods. The women, on the other hand, went to freshen up first and would ride horses later for leisure.

Li Cheng rode the Dawan horse that Huiyin had given him, and it was as if he had divine assistance, charging into the woods early on. Seeing this, Prince Wei shouted, "Exhilarating!"

Curious about how Li Cheng's hunt would turn out, Huiyin planned to settle the child and take a nap. It had been ages since she last rode for fun.

After helping Jing'er bathe, the mother and son slept deeply in bed.

When they woke up and arrived at Princess Wei's door, they learned that something had happened. It was said that Prince Wei's eldest son, Jing'er, was missing. Princess Wei and Consort Yin were anxious. As soon as Yin Liyi saw Huiyin, she asked, "Young princess, have you seen Jing'er?"

"No, how is it that despite so many people around him, he's missing?" Huiyin wondered if the child had wandered off somewhere while playing.

Consort Yin said, "He wanted to learn horse riding, but I told him he was too young and wouldn't allow it. So he went to find Master Xie. After that, we couldn't find him..."

As she spoke, Consort Yin broke down in tears and was ready to rush out to search for him.

Just then, a commotion erupted outside, and before Huiyin could greet them, Consort Yin ran up, crying, "Prince, Jing'er is missing! What are we going to do?"

Prince Wei also hurriedly said, "Yes, we've already sent servants to search the entire estate, but we couldn't find him."

"Where did the child go missing? Don't worry, I'll send people to search right away," said Prince Wei, his heart sinking. Though he favored Consort Xu more, he still cared deeply for Consort Yin and his eldest son.

As soon as he finished speaking, a servant reported, "Your Highness, Princess, Consort, the eldest prince has fallen into an old well. It's too deep, about a hundred meters, and it's surrounded by moss. No one dares to go down."

Huiyin feared that if the child had fallen into a moss-covered well, even if they managed to rescue him, he would likely be in grave danger, and the rescuer might risk their life as well. Who would be willing to take that risk?

Even Prince Wei hesitated. His generals were meant for battle, and besides, he had his beloved son Li Dun. How could he possibly send those skilled generals to risk their lives for a rescue?

Just as she was thinking this, Li Cheng spoke up, "Uncle, Aunt, we can't waste any more time. I'll go."

Huiyin quickly looked at her husband, not expecting him to step up at such a moment, and with such urgency.

Chapter 38

◎Combined Double Chapters◎

What was all of this for?

Huiyin was an extremely proud woman. After realizing that Li Heng had given her a sterility potion, she swiftly rebelled. But on the surface, she remained flawless. If she showed emotion toward you, it meant she considered you someone close to her. If she truly wanted to deal with you, you wouldn’t even know how you died.

Li Cheng was anxious to save the child. But instead of looking at her husband like everyone else, Huiyin looked at Yin Liyi. The gratitude in Yin Liyi’s eyes was filled with considerable affection. Honestly, Li Cheng had been very good to her—providing her with status, children, money, and even expressing his affection.

She had eyes and could see Li Cheng’s infatuation with her.

After learning who her husband’s heart truly belonged to, how should she react? Should she show cold detachment, explode in anger, make a scene, or choose to be outwardly warm but inwardly cold?

Huiyin quickly thought of a third path. She couldn’t rely on her family anymore; instead, she needed to build her own power base. If Li Cheng didn’t want to rebel, by the time he was strong with soldiers and horses, and their son had grown up, she and her son would co-rule the world. Li Cheng would have to listen, whether he wanted to or not.

For now, she couldn’t really get angry and push her husband into someone else’s arms.

Even if she didn’t want Li Cheng anymore, she had to make Li Cheng fall in love with her.

Therefore, when Huiyin heard Li Cheng’s words, she quickly reacted and grabbed Li Cheng’s hand, saying, “You’re too tall and broad-shouldered. We need to see if you can fit down that well first; otherwise, we might waste time rescuing them.”

If he were to die, it wouldn’t be now. In her past life, he had lived for several more years, so in this life, she would wait for a more suitable moment.

Li Cheng tightly held Huiyin’s hand and said, “It’s alright. Uncle Wei Wang has been very kind to me. Others have many concerns, so it’s perfect that I go.”

“Thank you, Little Prince,” Yin Liyi blurted out before Uncle Wei Wang could respond.

They all arrived at the well, and Huiyin looked down. It was unfathomably deep. Li Cheng had already started tying a rope around his waist. Before Huiyin could say anything, Yin Liyi, fearing that Huiyin would stop them, quickly pulled her aside and said, “Little princess, let’s wait here. Don’t disturb their rescue efforts.”

“Lady Xie, you don’t need to worry about me. I need to be there,” Huiyin pulled her hand away from Yin Liyi and still walked towards the well.

It was a dark, bottomless well, its narrow walls slick with moss. Li Cheng had a rope tied around his waist, and he was a bit afraid. After all, it was unfathomable, and he didn’t know if Li Jing was still alive. What if someone above had malicious intentions and cut the rope? Wouldn’t he die too?

For a moment, he regretted it. Although he was close to Uncle Wei Wang, if he died, wouldn’t all of Xuzhou’s troops and his own forces be absorbed by Wei Wang?

But he had to do it.

“Husband, go down slowly. I’ll watch from here.”

When Li Cheng heard Huiyin’s voice, his eyes welled with tears, but he blinked them back, feeling an overwhelming sense of relief. In critical moments, Huiyin was always there.

“Alright.”

Huiyin also heard Li Cheng’s voice. After a short while, everyone heard the commotion. Li Cheng carried Li Jing up with one arm, and they were both filthy. Li Jing had choked on water but was only unconscious. Once he was rescued, the doctor began pressing to expel the water.

When Yin Liyi heard the doctor say that her son was fine, she cried and laughed. It was on this day that she truly confirmed Li Cheng’s feelings. Li Cheng never expressed his affection, but today, in front of everyone, he risked his life to save her son. Coupled with how he had previously cared for Yin Liyi for her sake, Yin Liyi felt warmth in her heart.

Huiyin returned and arranged for hot water for them to bathe. She looked at her son who had just woken up and couldn’t help but think that if women had the same power as men, they wouldn’t have to depend on their families, husbands, or even their sons.

Relying solely on her son wasn’t a viable option. While a mother could wield influence when her son was young, once he grew older, she would be relegated to a position of honorary respect, unable to exert any real power.

But she couldn’t fight battles, had never learned military strategies, and couldn’t even read geographical maps. She could only rely on others.

Li Cheng took a hot bath, and when he came out, he saw Huiyin staring blankly. He laughed, and said, “What’s wrong? I didn’t even get a scratch.”

"I was wondering what you were doing when you went down just now. I understand we should save people, but Prince Wei hadn't given the order yet," Huiyin looked at him and said.

To her surprise, Li Cheng replied, "I said that for our own good as well. You'll see in the future."

Huiyin was puzzled. "For our own good? What do you mean?"

For some reason, Li Cheng seemed very pleased. "It's a good thing, anyway. Hey, I'm a bit hungry. Let's have the meal prepared."

Huiyin could only agree. She thought that regardless of whether it was for Yin Cifei, this had nothing to do with Yin Cifei anymore. Her priority was to win Li Cheng's heart.

They had hunted a lot that day, and the table was full of game. Huiyin had grown up eating mountain delicacies, and the cooking skills in Prince Wei’s mansion were excellent, which made her eat several more bowls of rice.

Li Cheng scooped a piece of meat onto her plate. "You don't know how reassured I felt when I heard you calling me as I went down the well."

"Of course. If you died for someone else, who would I mourn for? Don't do this kind of thing in the future." Huiyin said.

Li Cheng held her hand. "There are too many people here; I can't explain it to you. When we get home, I'll tell you the reason, don't worry."

Huiyin looked up at him and, for some reason, felt that Li Cheng seemed much more relaxed.

On the other side, Yin Cifei, seeing that her son had fallen asleep with even breathing, couldn't bear to leave and stayed by his bedside. It was her sister, Yin Liyi, who brought her meals.

"Sister, you must find out whether this was an accident or someone's foul play." Yin Liyi said seriously after putting down the tray.

Yin Cifei nodded. "I understand this. As you know, our Yin family has little influence. These years, we've relied on my son's status as the eldest son. But now they've started targeting Jing'er. Fortunately, the Prince of Huaiyin saved him today. If it had been any slower, the child might have drowned."

Yin Liyi smiled. "Sister, it seems the Little Prince has always had feelings for you."

Yin Cifei opened her mouth to scold her sister. "What nonsense are you talking?"

"I'm not talking nonsense. Don't try to hide it from me; I actually know. Back then, when the Little Prince was managing the Prince of Wei’s mansion, we sisters, along with Xue Huanhuan, worked together. He often put pressure on me, but I really learned a lot from him. So, at first, I shamelessly thought he liked me. But when he entrusted the birthday banquet to you, I realized he favored you." Yin Liyi smiled.

This incident had also brought attention to her sister's intelligence and cleverness. At that time, the Prince Wei’s Consort had been married for three years without giving birth, so her sister was made a concubine.

She didn't approve of her sister marrying the Prince of Wei. It wasn't that the Prince of Wei was bad; it was just that he liked too many people. Yin Liyi knew her sister didn't love the Prince of Wei either, but when the Prince of Wei wanted to marry her, who would dare to refuse?

Yin Cifei had been very cautious before, but today, seeing Prince Wei's hesitation and Li Cheng's bravery, old memories resurfaced. Back then, Li Cheng had told her that after this incident, she would stand out, and it would be proper for him to propose marriage.

But at that time, his mother had just died, and he had to return home. When he came back, everything had changed.

But for now, the most urgent thing was to find out who had harmed her son.

The Prince Wei’s Consort was also discussing this with the Prince of Wei. "The priority is to find the culprit; otherwise, the children in the family will not have peace in the future."

"But Jing'er hasn't woken up yet. The people around him said he ran to the well and disappeared. I've already ordered the wet nurses and servants to be punished. Don't worry, I'll give Jing'er an explanation." The Prince of Wei said.

Actually, what the Prince of Wei was most worried about was whether Li Cheng was supporting Yin Cifei. He had originally thought that since Yin Lifang came from a humble background, if she had given birth to a son, it would have been for the Prince Wei’s Consort. But the Prince Wei’s Consort had almost no influence over Li Cheng. He had a clear understanding of the dynamics within his household; Second Consort Xu was completely dependent on him, and the Huo family of the Prince Wei’s Consort was his strongest supporter in the Jiangnan region. Yin Cifei had already aligned herself with the Huo family.

Having the Huo and Xie families wasn't enough; now there was also the Prince of Huaiyin, Li Cheng, helping.

Li Cheng's abilities and talents were outstanding, and he had connections with the Yin family. Was he involved with Yin Lifang?

These were the real concerns that troubled him.

But as he thought about his son being pushed into the well, the Prince Wei’s Consort's accusations all pointed to Second Consort Xu. The Prince of Wei didn't think Second Consort Xu had done it. She didn't have that much influence. He was very clear about that.

The hunt would continue. The incident of Li Jing falling into the well was treated as a small matter. The next day, everyone, including the Prince Wei’s Consort and Yin Liyi, came except for Yin Cifei.

Today, all the ladies were dressed in riding outfits. Princess Wei glanced at Huiyin and thought that although she had previously found her magnificent and graceful, Huiyin now appeared especially dashing and valiant in her riding clothes. Huiyin had heard that they were going to play polo but hadn’t originally planned to participate. It wasn’t that she didn’t want to join; she just preferred to ride for a while.

Once polo was involved, there would be talk of winning and losing, which would be too exhausting. Since having a child, her energy levels weren’t what they used to be.

“Aunt—Princess Wei, I’ll get to know them first and ride to relieve my fatigue. My body is not what it used to be,” Huiyin declined politely.

Princess Wei didn’t insist.

Many of the ladies who had come were typical noblewomen from the south. They were generally slender and delicate, giving the impression of being quite small in stature. Huiyin noticed that they seemed to want to talk to her but were a bit shy, so she took the initiative to speak to them.

She didn’t say much, but after asking their names once, she could accurately remember them the second time. She spoke Mandarin but understood their Wu dialect fluently, with no trouble at all.

This was something she had learned by asking Li Cheng to teach her. Li Cheng was a man of his word, and Huiyin was very diligent in learning. Though she wasn’t yet at the point of speaking Wu dialect, she could almost fully understand it.

“Oh, you are General Lu’s wife. Pleased to meet you.”

“You are Granddaughter-in-law Gu, granddaughter of Grand Tutor Gu. Truly a distinguished family.”

Huiyin had now become acquainted with them. She rode her horse at a slow trot and felt refreshed. It had been a long time since she had enjoyed some time alone. Suddenly, she heard Yin Liyi cheering loudly from the side. Dressed in a fiery red riding outfit, Yin Liyi was smiling brightly.

Looking at Yin Liyi, Huiyin thought that people like her, who spoke directly and were somewhat insensitive, actually lived quite well. But what could Li Cheng possibly want to say to her?

Just as she thought this, Li Cheng rode over, concerned that she might feel isolated. Not wanting her to feel left out, he quickly approached.

“Why are you here? I just wanted to enjoy the breeze,” Huiyin looked at him. This wasn’t their own mansion, and it would look strange for a couple to be so close in public during the day.

Li Cheng smiled. “I was wondering why you weren’t playing polo with them. If you don’t know how, I can teach you.”

“It’s not that. I just want to ride for a bit on my own. Don’t make assumptions. Princess Wei always includes me in everything; it’s not a big deal,” Huiyin shook her head.

“Alright, I’ll ride with you then,” Li Cheng said, pulling the reins and walking slowly alongside her.

Huiyin was surprised. “Aren’t you supposed to be with Prince Wei today?”

Li Cheng replied, “They have their hands full today. I can do whatever I want.”

After riding a few steps together, unexpectedly, Princess Wei came over to call Huiyin herself. “Niece-in-law, someone was just replaced. Come on over.”

Huiyin agreed but added, “But I’m not very good at playing…”

Princess Wei wasn’t concerned. “It’s fine. We just need you to make up the numbers.”

Li Cheng was worried that Huiyin wouldn’t know how to play and was about to step forward, but Princess Wei intercepted him. “Little Prince, don’t worry. We’re just playing around and won’t take advantage of your wife.”

Huiyin also nodded at him. She had realized that while Li Cheng might not love her, he was definitely protective of his own. This was why, after his passing in her previous life, it was said that Zheng Deyin still received a regular stipend from him.

When choosing a husband, don’t just look for someone who treats you well. Look for someone who is fundamentally a good person.

In fact, Li Cheng was hesitant to watch Huiyin play polo. Seeing her reluctance, he assumed she wasn’t very skilled and decided not to watch. However, bursts of cheers erupted from the field.

Quan, the servant boy next to Li Cheng, said, “My lord, our princess is truly amazing. Just now, her horse’s head collided with someone else’s. I was worried sick.”

Only then did Li Cheng dare to look towards the polo field. The most eye-catching player was, of course, Yin Liyi, with her bright red clothes and large, sweeping movements. But he also saw a woman in green, swiftly maneuvering on horseback. Her horse was running so fast that she was even able to stand on it, perform a flip, and score another goal.

To everyone’s surprise, it was Huiyin.

It seemed her reluctance to join the polo game wasn’t because she couldn’t play, but because she was exceptionally good. Her riding skills were no joke.

Yin Liyi was also taken aback. She had always believed she was the best at polo among the women, but she never expected that someone as calculating as Huiyin could play so well.

Huiyin rarely felt so invigorated. As she came down from the field, she saw Li Cheng and quickened her pace toward him. Yin Liyi watched from the side, thinking that the young prince harbored feelings for her elder sister. On the surface, he seemed close to Princess Zheng, but deep down, his true affection was for Huiyin.

In fact, Li Cheng was helping Huiyin wipe the sweat from her face. If it had been any other woman, she would have been jealous. Though his wife had complaints in her heart, she still worriedly watched him by the well, not voicing her love but showing it through her actions.

"Is my face very red? That's why I don't like intense activities. Every time I move a lot, my face turns red like this," Huiyin said, drenched in a fine sheen of sweat, feeling a bit embarrassed as she looked at Li Cheng.

Li Cheng smiled and said, "You look great. In fact, with this activity, your complexion has improved."

Huiyin frowned slightly. "But I've twisted my waist."

The couple walked away, talking as they went. All of this was observed by the Princess of Wei, who thought that men were all masters of playing their roles. She remembered when she first entered the family, she had only one daughter, Jianjia, for three years. At that time, Yin Lifang was still a lady-in-waiting. Her family background was not prominent, and her appearance was merely elegant, not of breathtaking beauty. She was favored by the Grand Dowager, so the Princess of Wei did her a favor.

Over the years, she thought Yin Lifang's backer was at most the Xie family. Unfortunately, Xie Jiuyi suffered a military defeat. Now, with Li Cheng's favor, if Li Cheng truly loved the Second Consort Yin, there might be room for maneuvering.

Therefore, the Princess of Wei said to the people behind her, "This time, we must find evidence of who harmed the eldest young master, so we can give the Second Consort Yin an explanation."

The specific outcome was that, ten days later, Huiyin heard it was the wet nurse of Li Jing who played ball with him. The ball fell into the well, and Li Jing ran too fast. The wet nurse couldn't catch him, and he jumped into the well. The wet nurse, afraid, pretended not to know anything.

It was said that the wet nurse had been beaten to death.

Nanny Nan whispered, "Was this accident definitely orchestrated by the Second Consort Xu?"

"Why? Actually, it might not be. It could really be an accident. Without evidence, we can't make wild accusations," Huiyin said.

Nanny Nan said, "I heard that there is a concubine named Mo Ru who is pregnant and is currently by the side of the Prince of Wei. The Second Consort Xu is trapped between two dangerous situations, so she might have acted quickly."

Huiyin shook her head. "If she really did it, with her skills, she might end up being hurt by the tiger instead of defeating it."

Her methods were too low. In fact, this also had to do with the Prince of Wei himself. Of course, the Prince of Wei had his own reasons. Whenever someone urged him to establish an heir, he would say that the Princess of Wei was young and that he wanted to wait for the birth of his legitimate son.

In a moment of thought, they were about to leave. Happily, little Jing'er, the piglet, had no problems at all. Even Jing'er was surprised and asked Huiyin, "What magical elixir did you eat to have me?"

"Don't be silly," Huiyin said. She had irregular periods when she was in her maidenhood. Mainly because she was strong-willed and loved to compete, she exhausted herself.

Li Cheng lifted his son high, making Jing'er giggle, and the young father, full of energy, couldn't stop smiling.

Then they heard a young maid outside say, "Young Prince, Young Princess, the Second Consort Yin is here to express her gratitude with her child."

Li Cheng immediately looked at Huiyin and said, "I'll take Jing'er to the back."

Huiyin smiled and said, "No need. You saved someone, so you deserve their thanks. If you have a reason to tell me, I trust you."

There was no need for this secrecy, but Li Cheng got up and left.

Fortunately, the Second Consort Yin didn't show any disappointment when she didn't see Li Cheng. She gently stroked her son's head and said, "I'm here to express my gratitude. If it weren't for the young prince and you, what would have become of our Jing'er? He almost didn't make it."

"The young prince is righteous and always ready to help. Your Yin family has had connections with the Prince of Wei's Mansion in the past. This isn't an outsider. We can only hope that this child will bring about a change in fortune," Huiyin said with a warm smile. She wouldn't show any twisted jealousy, which was the lowest form of behavior, making a fool of oneself. If you lost your dignity, people would target you.

The Second Consort Yin smiled and nodded. "Yes. Young Princess, I'm not good with words, so I won't say much. This fine ge cloth was sent from Qiongzhou; it's great for making summer clothes for the child. And this white sable fur can be used for hats or coats. As for the tonics, please accept them as well."

It was evident that even as a secondary consort, her resources were limited. It was said that she still had to support her natal family. Huiyin nodded and said, "Then I won't be polite and accept them."

The Second Consort Yin looked very pleased. She knew that Li Cheng had feelings for her and would help her and her son, supporting her rise in status. This was better than anything else. As for Princess Zheng, she hoped that Li Cheng and Princess Zheng would live in harmony. Princess Zheng was the daughter of the Marquis of Zhaojie and the Grand Commander of Jizhou. If provoked, it would mean going against Zheng Fang, which wasn't necessary. Moreover, she also hoped that Li Cheng's daily life would be happy.

After staying at the hunting grounds for another day, they returned to the Prince of Wei's Mansion.

Naturally, Huiyin was eager to know what Li Cheng wanted to talk to her about, but she couldn't appear too anxious. She had to restrain herself and pay her respects to the Grand Dowager Wu. After her greetings, she was hungry and went to eat, then checked if her son had a fever.

When Li Cheng came in at night, she looked at him, and Li Cheng smiled and said, "Did you wait long? I was worried someone might overhear us. It's actually simple. Before my mother passed away, she asked me to marry her. But at that time, I had just joined the Prince of Wei's uncle, and she was a lady-in-waiting at the Prince of Wei's Mansion. I was also in mourning, so to fulfill this marriage, I needed the approval of the Prince of Wei's uncle and others."

"So she was engaged to you..." Huiyin was surprised.

Li Cheng said, "It was my mother’s dying wish. Let me finish. At that time, I was in charge of the Prince of Wei’s Mansion. She was diligent and hardworking, so I wanted to give her a chance to shine. Unexpectedly, she caught the eye of Wei Imperial Consort, and Uncle Wei Wang also agreed. As a nephew, how could I compete with my uncle? Alas, it was my fault. Even though she was supposed to be the Princess Consort, she ended up as a concubine. I can only try to make amends now. By saving her child this time, I feel I’ve finally repaid my debt to her."

Huiyin thought that Li Cheng was certainly not someone who could be forced into anything. He likely thought that despite her humble background, Yin Lifang’s virtues and abilities made her worthy of being a Princess Consort. He must have had some feelings for her. Otherwise, Yun Hui was chosen by his father to be a concubine, yet he didn’t follow through with that arrangement.

Still, she was grateful that Li Cheng told her the truth and did not hide it from her. Therefore, she said, "Thank you for being honest with me."

"You told me to give you my whole heart and not hide anything from you. Now, I’ve finally settled all my past debts. My heart is now free, and I’m ready to give it all to you. I keep my word," Li Cheng said frankly, because he believed that a woman who could still worry about his safety even when feeling jealous was truly worthy of love.

Huiyin thought that perhaps Yin Lifang would not see it that way. What if Yin Lifang thinks Li Cheng still has feelings for her, and they end up clashing?

title: Chapter 39
content:
Chapter 39

◎Update◎

After returning from the hunting grounds, Li Cheng went back to Xuzhou for an inspection and would return by the Winter Solstice. Huiyin personally went into the kitchen to prepare beef noodles and a sumptuous feast as a farewell gesture for her husband.

She wasn't the type to throw tantrums. Her son had already been conferred as the heir, and Li Cheng's estate of 200,000 taels was almost entirely managed by her. On usual days, besides her, there was no one else. He made time for her whenever he could. Although she didn't fully believe Li Cheng's reasoning for helping Yin Lifang so much out of guilt, her approach wasn't to be angry or sever ties but to elevate herself.

Thus, she smiled and said, "I noticed that Jianye is bustling with trade and filled with shops. However, I'm not interested in opening any other kind of shop, nor do I have the talent for it. How about we open a barbecue and noodle shop? These are two things I love to eat, and when I miss home, I can just go there."

Opening a small shop, of course, met with no objection from Li Cheng. He even remarked, "Isn't this a bit too small-scale?"

"Why would I do that? I know my limits," Huiyin replied confidently. She had ideas; she was inspired by the rice shop run by Hu JiaoJiao and realized she could establish a covert communication hub right in the city.

A small barbecue and noodle shop—who would suspect anything?

But with branches in Jianye, Xuzhou, Qingzhou, even Jizhou, and the capital, passing messages would be very convenient.

She wasn't going to tell Li Cheng about these plans just yet. Li Cheng, on the other hand, had already shared much with her. "In the future, you'll manage the accounts of our mansion. Don't worry about Grandmother; she's doing well now, chatting with those nuns every day, and someone keeps her company. I'm going to Xuzhou to also check on the situation in Qingzhou. I always feel that the tree desires stillness, but the wind will not cease. You don't know how much Uncle Wei Wang regrets losing Qingzhou."

Territory has to be fought for; no one will simply hand it over. Huiyin understood this principle. She even knew that in her past life, Li Heng went to Xuzhou and fought with Li Cheng's soldiers, resulting in countless casualties. If Li Heng weren't his own brother, he would have been dead by now.

But Li Cheng had also fought for several years and was shot by an arrow. It was said that he eventually died of poisoning while continuing to head north.

Huiyin felt compelled to plan for him now. "I understand, but you also need to think about yourself. The people from Empress Dowager Guo's family, though mediocre in talent, hold positions like Taiwei or the Three Dukes. You have plenty of soldiers and food, but you're only a Naval Commander. It's not that we're selfish, but people need to think about themselves."

"I understand," Li Cheng smiled.

Seeing that he didn't seem as repulsed as before, Huiyin felt a little more at ease and said to him, "Then later, I'll personally see you off."

Li Cheng was eating his noodles and nodded.

Once Li Cheng left, Huiyin began preparing for the noodle shop. The flour had to be brought from the north, and she took it directly from her dowry storage. The shop was opened in a busy market area. It wasn't large, and the name of the shop was very simple—"Zhang Laosan Noodle Shop."

The only thing different about this shop was its tables. The front few were small square tables, all second-hand purchases, while the tables at the back were charcoal grills, indicating that this place also served barbecue. The prices were affordable, even the drinks cost only two or three wen a cup, something everyone could afford.

Initially, people were intrigued by the sight of someone making noodles right there at the stove, but after trying it, they found it delicious, and the business gradually became very popular.

Seeing that the business was thriving, and with the first snow having fallen, Huiyin decided to host a "Plum Blossom Snow Banquet." She had attended many flower banquets, poetry gatherings, and elegant assemblies in the capital but had never hosted one herself. In her past life, she had been confined to the small space of the Eastern Palace, and later, as Empress Dowager, she didn't even host her own events.

Now, she used the "Plum Blossom Snow Banquet" as a theme to invite guests widely. Guests didn't need to bring gifts; they only had to wear clothes or accessories with plum blossom motifs.

Most people just needed to have invitations sent to them, but Princess Wei had to be visited personally by Huiyin.

Princess Wei was delighted to see Huiyin and, after reading the invitation, said happily, "Rest assured, I will bring Jianjia with me to support you."

"Oh, that's wonderful! I'm still new here and don't know much about these things," Huiyin said with a happy face.

Princess Wei then asked, "Did you only send me an invitation?"

Huiyin thought for a moment and said, "I came here personally to invite you. Besides that, I've sent invitations to the Huo family, the Lu family, and a few others."

Princess Wei smiled and pointed at Huiyin, "Didn't you realize you missed someone?"

"Please enlighten me?" Huiyin genuinely hadn't realized she missed anyone. After returning from the hunting grounds, several ladies had come to visit her, and she had invited people she was familiar with.

Princess Wei said, "You didn't invite Yin Lifang and Xu Ci-fei?"

Huiyin patted her forehead, "I thought that since you're the lady of the mansion, informing you would suffice. It's my fault."

Princess Wei was flattered by this compliment, as she indeed remained the undisputed mistress of Prince Wei’s Mansion, and the status of the two secondary consorts could not compare to hers. However, she remarked that Huiyin had not been attentive enough in her duties.

Huiyin obediently admitted her mistake.

Princess Wei was well aware that no matter how magnanimous Lady Zheng appeared, she likely harbored deep jealousy towards Second Consort Yin. What she didn’t know was that Huiyin was thinking about how Li Cheng must have liked Yin Lifang back then as well. Otherwise, why would he have risked his life to save her son before bidding her farewell? The deeper the love, the deeper the guilt, but it wasn’t necessarily an everlasting love. If it had been true love, he surely would have revealed himself by now.

As Li Cheng himself had said, true love means not letting the other person suffer. At the very least, if Li Cheng had truly cared for her, he wouldn’t have acted so recklessly in front of Prince Wei. If Prince Wei had suspected an affair, Second Consort Yin would have suffered greatly, and Li Cheng wanted to sever ties quickly.

To those who didn’t understand Li Cheng’s personality, his actions might seem strange. But Huiyin believed she understood him well enough. He was the type to act decisively, with strong execution, never dragging things out.

After returning from Prince Wei’s Mansion, the annual gifts from Jizhou had arrived. They were brought by Tong Niangzi, a trusted aide of Huiyin’s mother. Tong Niangzi had once led a group of women under Huiyin’s mother, and when Madame Ji remarried, she came along with her husband and son.

When Huiyin was young, it was Tong Niangzi who taught her how to ride a horse. Now, seeing Tong Niangzi again, she felt very close to her. “Aunt Tong, come in and sit down quickly. I wrote a letter earlier saying there’s no need to send gifts this year,” Huiyin said warmly.

Tong Niangzi smiled. “Madame is very concerned about you, especially after receiving your letter. However, I just heard from Nanny Nan that you were unwell. I believe Madame will be very happy to hear that you're better.”

“That was just a passing complaint of mine. Was it a snowstorm when you came?” Huiyin asked, holding her hand.

Tong Niangzi waved her hand. “The snow here isn’t cold at all.”

Huiyin shook her head. “The cold here is a damp cold. It’s cold both inside and outside, and we can’t even heat the kang. I really wish I could take the Prince back home with me someday and sleep on our family’s warm kang.”

Tong Niangzi patted Huiyin’s hand. “From what you’ve said, it’s clear that the Prince and you share a very good relationship.” She then asked how Prince Wei treated them.

“Prince Wei treats us very well, no complaints at all.” Despite feeling that Prince Wei was indecisive about choosing his heir, the civil and military officials in the Jiangnan region were all loyal to him.

Her own husband also had some prestige, but it would be difficult to surpass Prince Wei’s influence in Jiangnan.

Tong Niangzi also brought some news: “A lady-in-waiting from the Eastern Palace is pregnant. Although her background is humble, she is pregnant before our eldest miss. Madame Ji and Master are quite upset.”

Based on the timing, it should be Dong Yuniang. In her past life, Huiyin had struggled to outmaneuver Dong Yuniang, who was a formidable opponent.

“This lady-in-waiting was given by Empress He. It’s said that she was very lucky to become pregnant soon after entering the household. Now, the entire Eastern Palace is doting on her pregnancy.” Tong Niangzi sighed.

Huiyin thought that without her, Zheng Deyin and Lu Xiao would likely be unable to contain Dong Yuniang. And now, the only heir Li Heng wanted was from Dong Yuniang’s womb. Her low birth meant she had no backing, and Empress He could strengthen her relationship with Li Heng through this.

But Huiyin couldn’t reveal what she knew from her previous life. She could only say, “Since she can be pregnant, so can the Crown Princess. Perhaps our eldest miss will also become pregnant soon.”

“It’s been a few years since she married, and there’s been no sign of pregnancy. Empress He won’t let the Eastern Palace be idle. Now that Dong has been sent in, who knows how many more will follow.” Tong Niangzi was also tactful in her speech.

Huiyin smiled and shook her head. “This isn’t about luck. No one is born fortunate. It’s all about making things happen.”

In her previous life, Zheng Deyin often wrote to say that Li Cheng had someone in his heart. She had spent most of her days alone, almost like a widow, and now Huiyin had her own difficulties. But this wasn’t destiny; it was something to be fought for.

As Huiyin was preparing for the flower banquet, Tong Niangzi couldn’t stay long. She mentioned that Zheng Wuheng was getting married this year, and Madame Ji had already chosen a girl from a good family. Incidentally, this family was related to their Prince’s Mansion.

“You know that the famous clan in our Jizhou is the Qinghe Cui clan, whose daughter is the maternal cousin of the young prince. The girls from the Qinghe Cui clan are known for their elegance, dignity, and virtue.” Tong Niangzi praised them endlessly.

Huiyin thought that people like her, who had strong personalities, had to appear more dignified in public. After all, people didn’t like those who were too different, too ambitious, or too eager to express their desires. Even she only revealed a bit of her true self after giving birth to Li Cheng’s child and as their relationship flourished.

She had a fine banquet prepared and invited Tong Niangzi to drink. They talked a lot about the Zheng family. Tong Niangzi had to leave the next day, saying she couldn’t stay any longer due to pressing matters at home. No matter how much Huiyin insisted, she wouldn’t stay, so Huiyin prepared generous gifts for her to take back.

After Tong Niangzi left in a hurry, Huiyin felt a deep sense of loneliness. She hadn’t missed home for a long time, having been married for so many years, and returning to her family home felt like being a guest.

But as the snow gently fell outside, a sudden longing for home washed over her. She wanted to take Li Cheng back to her family home for a visit. Her mother missed her the most and was always concerned about her well-being.

title: Chapter 40
content:
Chapter 40

◎Combined Double Chapters◎

Huiyin's first Plum Blossom Snow Banquet was about to begin, and the entire Huaiyin Mansion was adorned with a plum blossom theme. The first guest to arrive was Mrs. Lu, the young wife of the Lu family from Wuxing. Though young, she was held in high esteem among middle-ranking official wives. Yet, at an event in a mansion like this, someone of her status needed to arrive early to pay her respects.

People often show one face to their superiors and another to their inferiors. Isn’t that just the way things are?

She entered through the west corner gate, where a warm sedan chair awaited her. As Mrs. Lu was about to board, she noticed the curtains were adorned with a deep red background and crisscrossing ice patterns, featuring the design of "happiness on the plum blossom," exuding an elegant and noble air.

Once inside the sedan chair, a subtle fragrance surrounded her. Plum blossoms have a very subtle scent that can easily go unnoticed unless you pay close attention. But inside the enclosed space of the chair, the fragrance seemed to gather, creating a mysterious and elusive aroma.

After disembarking from the chair, a group of servant women greeted her. Though they didn’t wear any plum blossom insignia, their earrings featured various plum blossom designs.

For instance, Lady Liu, who came to receive her, was in her thirties. Though a servant, she wore unique wax plum and green branch earrings, which gave Mrs. Lu the impression that this was indeed the distinguished Huaiyin Mansion.

Even the spacious corridor where she usually paid her respects had been transformed. In winter, with cold winds on all sides, screens had been used as barriers. These screens were adorned with plum blossom designs, elegant yet not overly intricate.

As she entered the Cloud Pavilion to admire the plum blossoms, she saw golden silk curtains with a misty haze over the snow. Amid this, sat a person dressed in light green silk double-nest cloud goose palace attire, wearing a gold-threaded silver diadem. She sat gracefully amidst the opulence, looking ethereal.

Huiyin, seeing that the first guest was Mrs. Lu, nodded inwardly. In the past, she always hoped to convince everyone in her interactions. If even one person remained unconvinced, she would feel she hadn’t done enough. But now, her approach had changed. She needed to select two people who were more supportive of her, both of whom should have considerable prestige and could help her gather a group of supporters. When their husbands and sons encountered difficulties in their official careers, she could ask Li Cheng to help, thereby securing their loyalty. These merits would ultimately reflect on her.

Mrs. Lu was an ideal candidate for this. But first, she needed to get close to her. Huiyin had noticed during a previous event that Mrs. Lu had been watching her the entire time.

"This humble one, Lu Hongshi, pays my respects to the young princess," Mrs. Lu knelt and bowed.

After she stood up, Huiyin pretended to be puzzled and said, "Have we met before? I wonder where you are from?"

Mrs. Lu, who had been nervous because these high-ranking figures could be difficult to serve, felt a surge of joy at Huiyin's seemingly confused expression. However, she replied respectfully, "This humble one grew up in Jianye and has not traveled far."

"Oh, then I must have been mistaken. Please, sit and let's talk," Huiyin said lightly.

Mrs. Lu saw this as an opportunity to ingratiate herself. She felt that although the young princess was high above her in status, they shared a lot of common topics. Even after other guests arrived, she believed the young princess would still pay attention to her, which filled Mrs. Lu with a sense of honor.

More guests arrived, including Lady Gao, who brought three young ladies, and Lady Huo, who came with her daughter-in-law and two daughters.

Lady Huo smiled and observed, "This place is well-chosen. From here, you can see a view of red plum blossoms. Young princess, your attire today also complements the scene—red plum blossoms and green clothes."

"Madam flatters me. Ladies, please try this tea. It’s brewed with melted snow from the plum blossoms," Huiyin said with a smile.

Everyone began to drink the tea. Some were true connoisseurs, while others were less discerning. But those who knew about the elaborate preparation process of the tea would undoubtedly consider it excellent, even if they didn’t fully understand its quality.

Mrs. Lu felt that the young princess regarded her highly, which warmed her heart. Naturally, she praised Huiyin both privately and publicly, saying, "Young princess, you have arranged this place so beautifully. Look, there are wind lanterns hanging on the plum blossoms over there. It feels like a secluded path that suddenly opens up, allowing us to admire the resilience of the plum blossoms blooming in the cold."

Just as she was speaking, Princess Wei and others arrived. Huiyin stood up to welcome them. Both Yin the secondary consort and Xu the secondary consort had brought gifts. Upon their arrival, Huiyin ordered the banquet to begin.

The sounds of zithers, flutes, and ancient harps drifted over, not too loud but sufficient to enjoy the music.

The guests marveled at the chairs and tables, crafted from luxurious golden nanmu wood, which left them all amazed. Yin Liyi quietly said to her sister, "The Huaiyin Mansion is truly rich and luxurious, much better than your usual expenses, sister."

Yin Lifang shushed her and looked at her sister with affection, "You, silly girl, you have children of your own now and still speak so freely."

"I only tell you, sister. I wouldn’t say this to others. Look, there are so many dishes prepared." Yin Liyi was once again drawn to the food. The first cold dishes served included jade goose threads, crystal brawn, and jade dew fragrant diagram—all reportedly delicacies passed down from the palace.

Yin Lifang, on the other hand, sipped her wine and observed Princess Zheng, who sat below Princess Wei. She was surrounded by attendants and looked completely at ease, as if born to such wealth and elegance. Such a life was truly enviable. Her status allowed her to display her wealth with ease, but she also managed the household admirably.

She didn't want to cause any disruption at someone else's residence because of her.

Huiyin was smiling as she toasted Princess Wei. Princess Wei drank a cup of wine and praised Huiyin for doing a great job.

After the banquet, people were either enjoying the plum blossoms, playing arrow toss, or engaging in board games, drinking tea, and eating snacks. Everyone was content and at ease.

Huiyin had several boxes of palace-made flowers brought in. Originally, she hadn’t planned a poetry gathering, but seeing that many young ladies had come, she had a desk prepared and asked Princess Wei, "Among these ladies, do you know who is the most skilled in calligraphy and painting?"

Princess Wei mentioned a few names, and Huiyin gladly accepted, saying to them, "This is a plum blossom banquet, and there will be a prize for the best poem."

"There's no need for you to provide a prize. I have one here," Princess Wei said, taking out a white jade plum blossom hairpin.

Huiyin clapped her hands and laughed. "With such generosity from Aunt Princess, that's even better."

Everyone laughed again. As the hostess, Huiyin proposed a topic and set a rhyme scheme. Eventually, the third young lady from the Huo family was chosen as the top poet, making the banquet a complete success.

After this plum blossom banquet, Huiyin received many invitations to other banquets. She wanted to write to the Little Prince to ask for advice, because if she asked others, they might not tell the truth. Like Princess Wei, her words sounded grand but were not trustworthy. Li Cheng, however, was a man who took things seriously. Sometimes, even though he was high-ranking, his words were quite reasonable.

The main issue was that there were many factions here, and offending any of them would be bad. This place was not like Xuzhou, which was Li Cheng's territory.

The letter she sent reached the Little Prince after three days. He was handling official business and, upon seeing Huiyin's letter, opened it first. Fearing she might be in a hurry, he immediately replied.

After replying, he re-read Huiyin's letter. She mentioned that her family had sent festival gifts and that she wanted to return home to visit her family. Li Cheng found this somewhat troublesome, as they were supposed to go to Jizhou, and the timing wasn't good. Moreover, his identity was quite sensitive. Prince Wei intended to take Qingzhou, and Li Cheng was the first choice for the task. With his capabilities, both Qing and Xu states would be under his control.

Staying in Jianye would become unsafe. In the past, he had been loyal to Prince Wei, but now, as he grew older, new thoughts began to emerge.

He wanted to carve out his own path, something he had never even dared to imagine before. Lü Wei, He Jin, and Wei Duo were all of his grandfather's generation. He had only sought a place to settle, but now he felt he might be able to trust himself. Additionally, Jing'er was in good health, and who knows, maybe he could fight like him and inherit a kingdom. Perhaps his son could even unify the world.

Shaking his head, he reminded himself that he was a pragmatic person and shouldn't think too much.

At noon, he ate the baked buns Huiyin had sent over. The lamb inside was fragrant. Li Cheng wiped his face, thinking, "I can't be so weak as to miss my wife like this."

Upon receiving the Little Prince's reply, Huiyin looked at the several pages and couldn't help but laugh, "This is too detailed."

Fugui chimed in, "That's because the Little Prince values you highly and replied quickly upon seeing your letter."

"I just wish time would pass quickly so he could return," Huiyin said, reopening his letter, extracting key figures, comparing it with the invitations, and selecting a few families to maintain good relations with.

Nanny Nan brought a cup of hot tea and placed it in front of Huiyin. "Young Princess, please have some tea."

"Thank you," Huiyin said, noticing Nanny Nan's hesitation and smiling, "If you have something to say, just say it."

Nanny Nan shook her head. "I always feel that our Little Prince is too loyal to Prince Wei. I see that Prince Wei is an ambitious person. Governor Xie's initial failure means he will likely have to rely on our Little Prince in the future. I'm just afraid that the Little Prince will go to war."

Huiyin was somewhat worried but smiled and said, "As a soldier, this is how it is. If you don't fight others, they will fight you. Look at my father; every time he goes out, my mother is worried to death. It's a life-and-death situation."

People often downplay the dangers others face, offering comfort easily, but when it comes to their own loved ones, they feel the weight much more deeply.

It was also mentioned that while attending these banquets, Huiyin had her subordinates open noodle shops in places like Wuzhong and Kuaiji near Jianye. These shops were nestled in the bustling market, their facades neither too old nor too new, and their prices kept low to attract customers.

This year, since she was spending the New Year in Jianye, she sent a New Year gift to the newlywed bride, Hu Yan Yan. Her gift was a timely relief, almost saving Hu Yan Yan.

As she attended more banquets, Huiyin began to realize that this place wasn’t always so obedient to Prince Wei. Although Prince Wei appeared magnanimous, he was actually more intelligent and cunning. He first won over those who surrendered to him and then had them fight among themselves. Eventually, they all surrendered to him.

He was indeed cunning and capable. Compared to him, Li Cheng seemed more naive and compassionate, a man who was cold on the outside but warm inside. Perhaps it was due to their different upbringings. The Prince of Wu and his wife had only one child, Li Cheng, whom they doted on, raising him to be confident, generous, and responsible. Prince Wei, though young, had experienced much under various powers, making him quite deep.

"Young Princess, both Lady Lu and Lady Gao are coming together," someone reported.

Huiyin smiled and said, "Please invite them in."

These two were the representatives she chose. As soon as Lady Lu entered, she smiled and said, "Just now as I came in, I saw the yellow oriole under the corridor of the young princess's residence chirping joyfully. We have a piece of good news to tell you today."

Huiyin had tea prepared for them and asked, "I wonder what this good news is?"

Lady Gao said, "Last time you mentioned that the local tea here is excellent. Coincidentally, a tea merchant is looking to sell, so we came to inform you. When he heard that you are the buyer, he said he would just give it to you."

"That won't do. I'll send someone to ask if he's genuinely looking to sell. If he is, we'll pay the proper amount of silver for it." Huiyin had witnessed too many instances of coercion and bullying by those in power, and she refused to engage in such practices.

At times, she felt a strange kinship with Li Cheng—both knowing the truth but lacking the heart to act on it.

After buying the tea plantation, she would still need help to manage it, but that would be a matter for next year. When she visited the Wei Mansion, she heard Princess Wei teasing her, "I heard you've started a business recently?"

Huiyin smiled and said, "I mentioned that I found the tea here good, and someone happened to say a tea plantation was for sale. I went to take a look, and it was indeed well-maintained, so I bought it. I hope you won't mock me, Aunt."

Princess Wei said, "Which of us women doesn't have some private savings? When I got married, it was the same. But since you married far away, you probably hadn't had the chance to set anything up. This is indeed good."

Huiyin nodded and said, "You are right, Aunt."

She had come to deliver seasonal gifts. Li Cheng had originally planned to return, but he sent a letter saying he couldn't make it. Huiyin felt a sense of emptiness, but keeping herself busy helped.

At this time, she heard that Yin Liyi was pregnant. Although she wasn't particularly close to Yin Liyi, Li Cheng had a good relationship with Xie Jiuyi, so she had visited once.

During this visit, she met Lady Xie. Lady Xie was very kind and treated Yin Liyi like her own daughter. Huiyin thought that it would be wonderful if Lu Xiao could marry into such a family. She hadn't understood why Yin Liyi had married into the Xie family, given the difference in status, but now she knew that the marriage had been arranged by Prince Wei. Consort Yin had asked Princess Wei to help, and Xie Jiuyi genuinely liked Yin Liyi, so they were happily married.

Consort Yin prevented her father from receiving an official post but arranged for her sister to marry the prefect of Bohai, a position of real power. This was indeed clever, though Huiyin suspected it was more about good fortune, which could be the best part of life.

Zheng Deyin lamented her own lack of luck and fortune. The Crown Prince often visited her, but she hadn't conceived.

Unexpectedly, Lianzhi rushed in, panic-stricken, and said, "Consort Liangdi, something terrible has happened. Dong Yuniang has been killed... killed by Prime Minister Lü Wei."

Zheng Deyin fell to the ground, shocked.

In the main hall of the Eastern Palace, Crown Prince Li Heng was pleading, "Prime Minister, Dong Yuniang's brother absolutely did not mean to offend."

Seeing Li Heng begging desperately, Lü Wei smiled and said, "Crown Prince, firstly, the Dong family disrespected the Crown Princess. The Crown Princess has no child, yet a child from a concubine was born first. Secondly, the brother attempted to assassinate me. Do you have anything to say in defense?"

Li Heng had never been so humiliated, but he had no choice but to plead. At least for now, he could still go out to fight battles, but in the future, he might not even be allowed to leave and could be imprisoned.

Dong Yuniang had thought that becoming pregnant would elevate her status, but now her life was gone. She begged Li Heng, "Your Highness, you told me that if I had your child, I should serve the Crown Princess more. I carry your flesh and blood."

Li Heng looked at her, feeling some pity, but still said, "I can barely protect myself."

Dong Yuniang, whose hopes had soared so high, now closed her eyes and wept uncontrollably as Lü Wei ordered her to be taken away. This was the first time Zheng Deyin had seen someone so lively and even defiant in front of her become bloodied. She fell ill from the shock.

Elder Madame Xu and Madame Ji went to the palace to visit her. Elder Madame Xu had heard the rumors, but the Zheng family was not like the Dong family, which had no foundation or power. Still, she feared that Lü Wei might act recklessly.

"Grandmother, it was so terrifying... really terrifying..." Before, when she was in the Huaiyin Mansion, even though she had been sent to Jianye to be with Grand Dowager Wu, Lady Xun, and others, and lacked her husband's affection, at least there was no threat to her life. Even if Li Cheng died, someone would still take care of her.

She had once thought marrying Li Cheng was like living in hell, but now, under Li Heng, she faced true turmoil. If only Father could have eliminated Lü Wei.

"Grandmother, ask Father to kill Lü—"

Before she could finish, Madame Ji slapped her. "Consort Liangdi, there are many ears here. Prime Minister Lü is a benefactor to our Zheng family. Why say such things?"

Elder Madame Xu looked at her, troubled. "You are a Liangdi now. The Crown Princess of the Eastern Palace can't even go home, much less you. There are many troubles in the palace now, but you'll be fine. I've asked your father to guarantee it."

"But I’m really scared..." She was truly scared.

She even wondered if the rumors from her previous life, claiming that Dong Yuniang was killed by Huiyin, might also have been orchestrated by Lü Wei. No, that couldn’t be, because if Zheng Huiyin could persuade her father to kill Lü Wei, why couldn’t she do the same? After all, she was also her father’s daughter.

Elder Madame Xu glanced at Madame Ji, who lowered her head. She couldn’t possibly take her in. If she were truly pregnant, Zheng Fang might still have a chance to help her. But now, she had nothing, so how could anyone assist her? Besides, Zheng Deyin was not her own daughter, so why should she say more, as long as it didn’t involve her own family?

After the New Year, spring arrived quickly. The ice on the lake broke, and boats could sail again.

Jing'er would be turning one in two or three months. He was different from other children. He was very strong and had already started eating solid food—rice porridge, fish paste, meat paste, and even fruit puree, which he enjoyed immensely.

"Your father probably won’t be able to lift you." Huiyin said with a smile.

She had received a letter from Li Cheng two days ago, saying he was very tired from non-stop training.

Why was he training so intensively day and night? The court had just taken Qingzhou and was in a period of rest and recovery. It was unlikely that war would break out so soon. Why was he working so hard?

However, Consort Xu knew first. As the confidante of the Prince of Wei, she often received firsthand information. Even Princess Wei didn’t dare to overly suppress her. For instance, the last incident involving the investigation into Li Jing being thrown into a well eventually fizzled out without any conclusion.

"I didn’t expect this Little Prince Jing'er to be such a sentimental person." She said with a smile.

Her trusted aide said, "Didn’t you previously mention that he had connections with Consort Yin, and that you were worried he might support Consort Yin’s son as the heir? Why are you now saying he’s sentimental towards the young princess?"

Consort Xu smiled. "One thing at a time. Although there seem to be many capable people around the prince, the one he appreciates the most is this nephew of his. Unless absolutely necessary, the prince won’t break with him. But the future is hard to say."

The aide was confused. "What do you mean?"

"Don’t you know the saying: 'When the hares are dead, the hunting dogs are cooked; when the birds are gone, the bows are put away; when the enemy is defeated, the strategists are discarded'?" Consort Xu said coldly.

The aide shuddered upon hearing this.

As for Huiyin, she had been playing with Jing'er all morning. The child was so energetic that she couldn’t handle it anymore and needed a nap. However, she woke up suddenly, feeling as if someone was kissing her. Startled, she realized it was Li Cheng.

"Hey, when did you get back? You didn’t say anything." Huiyin said, noticing his dusty and smelly appearance.

Li Cheng smiled. "Didn’t you say you wanted to return home to visit your family? So, I’ve been training the troops day and night, preparing defenses, and then volunteered to go to the capital to celebrate the emperor’s birthday. That way, I can take you with me, right?"

Touched that he had taken her words to heart, Huiyin sat up and reached for his hand. "Really?"

"When have I ever said something fake? Even Uncle Wei agreed!" Li Cheng said with a smile.

Huiyin knew that Li Cheng didn’t really like her father. As his daughter, she understood Zheng Fang’s character better—someone who betrayed his lord to rise to power and rebelled multiple times. Li Cheng, being upright, definitely disapproved of him. Now, for her sake, he was putting himself in danger. If something happened to him in the capital, how could she face him?

"You fool, forget it. I only mentioned it in passing. I don’t really want to go back. As long as we’re together, that’s all that matters." Huiyin said.

Li Cheng quickly added, "It’s not just for you. I also want to go to the capital to see how things are changing. If I don’t even have the courage for this, how can I lead troops into battle in the future?"

Seeing that Huiyin was still unhappy, he continued, "I actually didn’t want to go back either. It’s not a wise move right now. But I just thought that if we went back together, you’d be happy."

"With such a tender heart, how will you ever become a ruler?" Huiyin said with a tearful smile. In this aspect, he was much better than Li Heng, who was ruthless.

Li Cheng deliberately put on a serious face. "Enough talk. We have limited time. Let’s pack quickly."

Huiyin gently said, "Yes."
